Posted: December 29, 2015
												I'm sure this review will go unnoticed but that doesn't matter.This game is seriously one of my favorite of all time. Yeah, just another EA racing game released in the 7th generation, but it's a very special EA racing game released in the 7th generation. The best EA racing game released in the 7th generation. Hell, probably the best EA racing game of all time in my book (NFSMW, B3, NFSU2 are all extremely close).PROS:-Beautiful detail. Every crash and car looks spectacular, and some views are simply jaw-dropping.-Hours upon hours of replayability. And when you do get 100%, you have a nice feeling inside.-Some of the best licensed and original music. Also, incredible classical music.-An awesome city known as Paradise City. Pretty big, and has a personality of it's own, in a way.-Very unique things you can do in the game: Ever wanted to barrel roll an F1 car into a quarry while being stalked by Black Armored Cars?CONS:-Of course, with such a large world, there will be very tedious and annoying moments at times.-Depending on the person, this will be a glaring flaw: the only real character, DJ Atomika, is a bit of a jerk.Really good game. If you like racing games, it's a must have. 4/5

number of helpful: 1,061 of 1,309 people (81%) found this review helpful50 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Burnout Paradise is an open world, survival horror game developed by Criterion Games, who are most known for making popular racing titles. The game is set in a horrific post-apocalyptic city, ironically called Paradise City. I can assure you however, there is no paradise to be seen in this hellish landscape.You play as an unnamed, sentient car. The game revolves around completing the same missions over and over in order to upgrade your licence, to prove that you are king of the cars. The missions mostly involve destroying other cars, however, there are some racing elements involved here and there. As a working class peasant who cannot afford a luxury sports car, this appeals to my deep seated resentment of people who have more money than me.[SPOILER ALERT] The story is fantastic. Towards the end of the game, you discover that you are not the protagionist at all. In fact, you are the villian. The real hero of the game is a DJ driven to madness named Atomica. Who has been broadcasting Paradise City's only radio station the entire game. His true motives are to get all of the cars in the city to destroy eachother, so that he can free humanity from its chains and rebuild society. Many games have tried to copy Burnout Paradise's clever plot twist, and have failed miserably. Ken Levine, eat your heart out. You can never hope to recreate this masterful storytelling.In summary, Burnout Paradise is a masterpiece. There isn't a single game in existence that can match its artistic calibre. So I award this game ten out of ten cars. You will never get TYRED of this game.(A lot of people are leaving comments pointing out the similarities to Yahtzees review. Fine, but Yahtzee wasn't the only person to think of this. This was meant to be a small joke amongst friends that just happened to get popular. Whining won't make me take it down.)

												10/10Pros:- Well what can I say, Burnout Paradise is the best sandbox racer that was ever made period. - I got over 240hrs of playtime on PS3. - Best 240hrs spent on a racer in my life. - If you buy this game, invest over 5-6 hours into it and I assure you will be hooked for another 50. Unlocking cars, finding all the jumps/shorcuts/garages/billboards is fun.The single player is a blast. The online portion is also. I was amazed that there is still plenty of people playing this online on steam, even late into the life of this game. I don't mind coming back to it every now and then. The best thing about coming back to this game is that I still have a blast like during the first 240hrs I played this game.Cons: - Too bad that the ultimate box on steam doesn't come with Big Surf Island. - You can't add your own music playlist easily like in the console version.Since this Ultimate box doesn't come with Big Surf Island and plenty of optional awesome cars in DLC format. I better go add my precious time on the PS3 version and start a new game again. - God I love this game.- I and plenty of other gamers still wish Criterion would make a sequel to Paradise. Because we would throw our money right into the screen if we ever see an annoucement trailer for a Paradise sequel.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is a great racing game that's all about driving in the open world of people-free Paradise City, of which the title song claims has green grass and pretty girls.  Along the way, you'll be bombarded with advertising billboards for such things like Burger King, EVGA motherboards, Crash FM, and this very game.  Sadly, you can only demolish one of these billboards, which keep reappearing continuously.  Somehow, I feel real sorry for the cleanup crews having to fix up the damage caused by driverless cars.  It's like Twilight Zone stuff, man!While you repeat the events that you've already cleared with each new license, you get to hear a selection of licensed songs that usually repeat a pretty good deal.  Or you can listen to past Burnout songs from a time Acclaim published those games.  Maybe you just feel like listening to that Avril Lavinge song over and over.  Did you know that song was also in Burnout Dominator AND in multiple languages?  There are also classical songs in the game, but nobody listens to those. ;)The damage model is quite glorious, parts flying off, cars flipping about, and [my favorite /s] the game going into super slow motion because you were too slow in reacting to a barrier right in front of you.  It's like you know you're going to be taunted mercilessly, especially if you crash mere seconds before the time trial expires.  But if you feel like crashing into things and causing mass destruction, there is a Showtime mode.  It's not quite like the crash modes in previous games, but it counts for something.Even with the minor flaws like the lack of a certain bit of DLC that the potato consoles got to enjoy, super slow motion crashes that test your patience, and the general grind with each new license, this is still a very enjoyable racing game that people continue to play to this day.

number of helpful: 45 of 56 people (80%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												A case of paradise found, or paradise lost?I've played all Burnout games since Point of Impact, except Dominator. Paradise seemed just as exciting as previous titles in the series to begin with, but by the end it became an exercise in anger management. Having completed it on the PS3 I thought coming back to it on PC was going to be a cakewalk. If only.Enjoying Paradise depends on a lot of ifs. Where you are at in the game, how much you intend to play, and how easily things annoy you, for starters.The game dumps you on a map and basically says 'Enjoy!', leaving you to discover everything it offers for yourself. Perhaps the first and biggest wonder you'll notice is the miraculous lack of people - even the random cars you see on the road are all empty. Even your own car. Compared to games like GTA this is a bit of a sore point for me - having someone to run over and some voice-acting to laugh at would have been a nice addition. The only voice there is to listen to (besides the soundtrack / music) is DJ Atomica, who never ceases to bring you down with some disparaging remark when you lose an event. Sometimes he's ok, but the game would have been better off without his five pence of 'try harder' and 'the route you choose' bull.If driving around in Robot City isn't a problem for you then you might like this title. There is a big garage of awesome looking cars to unlock, and the freedom of having a huge map fully unlocked already means you can pick and choose which roads to use in races and events. Occasionally it can get confusing, but the option is there to check an event's route before you start it, so you can take your time deciding how best to navigate the roads to get to where you need to as fast and effortlessly as possible.Collectibles include challenges (both offline and online - online lists challenges for each of 2 players through to 8 players); smashes (which are construction fences that often fence off short-cuts); billboards (for smashing through as well); and super jumps. Just finding all of these can be a chore. In addition, each road has a fastest lap record to beat, and a crash mode record to beat. Some roads are little, others are huge. Crash mode isn't quite the same as previous games though, where you get a specific set-up and have a bunch of buses all packed together in the distance. Instead, while driving you can start crash mode at the touch of a button (but careful not to start it in the middle of a race). The goal here is to rack up a big $$$ of carnage, hitting traffic, buses, signs, anything with a $$$ painted over it. The event stops when your boost bar empties, but is filled regularly as long as you keep hitting things. This is one of the more fun aspects of the game, but it can be frustrating too, as all too often the crash traffic will spawn on roads you can never possibly reach, sometimes you'll see traffic spawn in the distance only to de-spawn before it reaches you (possibly because too much traffic is spawning on other roads), and traffic has an awful habit of avoiding your bouncing wreck trying to aim for them. Overall it's fun, but I get the feeling it needs a patch or something.Event types are colour-coded on the map, thankfully, as there are over a hundred and finding what you want can be problematic. They are broken down into races, burning routes (car-specific race against the clock), stunt runs, road rages (using your car to take out other cars within a time limit), and marked man (which is the biggest pile of doo-doo since Jurassic Park).The goal of the game is to keep unlocking new licences, ending with the Burnout Elite licence, requiring you to complete everything. Up until this last licence it is possible to avoid most events you don't like, but this last licence forces you into events you may hate. For me it was Marked Man - an event that is akin to a bull in a china shop, with you playing as the china. It seems to me too heavily reliant on dumb luck just to survive the longer distances - repair drive-thrus often being too few or too far away to be of any use. I see it as utterly preposterous and totally unnecessary. Sometimes all you can do is sit and watch in sheer disbelief as attack cars rain down on your humble car from every possible angle, sometimes t-boning you mere seconds after respawning, leaving you no room to escape at all. And to top it all off DJ Atomica will whine at you afterwards, saying you have no skill.Apologies to my brother, Grunner, and my family for all the foul language and violence when I started doing Marked Man.It's a shame but I believe Marked Man events will be a game breaker for perfectionists looking to get 100%. It can be done, but you may find items around you will get broken in your rage. Lots of excessive cinematics in the menu and waiting for cars to drop in before you can choose them to drive make the game unnecessarily longer. The menu is messed up to begin with - you use F1 and F2 to navigate various menus and a web page - not to mention the fail webpage that still tries to load every time you start the game.But the visuals are pretty good considering the game's age, and the soundtrack is pretty beast. If you're a racing fan, need more cars to play with and there's nothing better out there, then you'll get this despite the menu problems or stupid Marked Man. Due to all the enjoyment I've had I can't recommend against it, but it's pretty close. 50/50. Racing probably isn't for me.

												The best racing game ever created. Don't be fooled by my playtime, I have spent over 4000 (yes, fourthousand) hours in this game on my PS3 since it came out back in 2008. I miss the old times, I don't regret any hour I spent in Paradise City and I will always remember every single player I made friends with. I guess it's not the same nowadays, but there won't be any game like this, ever again. I'm a little bit sad that my children won't experience something like this. content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												One of the most frustrating games to play I've ever seen. It forces you to log-in via EA's log-in system, which is frustrating to no end before you even begin the game. Then it forces you to sit through an unskippable cutscene telling you how to drive a car, and how wonderful this great city you'll spend your time driving around in. Followed by a tutorial to teach you which button is the gas pedal. Followed by unskippable cutscenes explaining every single race. It's like they knew this would be a horrible game, so they make you sit through as many cutscenes as possible so you can't actually play. What was the biggest deal-breaker, besides the boring gameplay, the constant cutscenes, and the didactic edification? You can't quit the game without being froced to pass through EA's "Burnout Store" so they can panhandle you to make in-game purchases. Speaking as a lover of the Burnout series, this is a sleazy and nasty puddle of bile on top of a poorly made game. There are infinitely better racing/driving games. Play those.

Posted: February 4
												First off, this is an awesome racing game, and its worth the buy, especially if its on sale. The environments are beautiful and varied, and just free driving around to kill time is fun as hell. But I feel the need to address things I saw in other reviews, so here goes.1. YOU CAN PLAY WITHOUT LOGGING IN. I forgot my login so I just have to start over. Simply hit cancel and on the next screen, "return to game". It will let you play offline only. Only thing is without that login you can't play online.2. There are graphics and controls options. They're in the "Configuration" launch option.3. Controllers seem to work fine. My 360 controller is plug and play no issues. (RB changes music) 4. Ignore the people complaining about the unrealistic physics or lack of a speedometer or manual. It's a game with arcade roots. It's not trying to be Gran Turismo.All in all it's a fun, addictive racing game that can be kinda annoying in terms of difficulty later on, but its pretty damn fun, with an awesome sense of speed.One knock on EA for not making the DLC part of the package and hard as **** to get your hands on, especially since this is supposed to be an "Ultimate" box.My rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
-Quick Review-Welcome to Paradise island, the island where you can run over almost everything, jump over everything else, and crash with little to no consequences. Burnout Paradise is an Open World racing game developed by Criterion Games and released in 2009.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You start the game with a quick introduction to Paradise Island, after your introduction you try to accumulate “marks on your licenses” to progress to the next licenses and unlock new vehicles.You earn Marks on your license by completing the various challenges, there is always a challenge at every intersection.... leaving you plenty of races, bumper cars, stunt drives, and chases to keep people entertained.The primary vehicles you'll play as are Cars, but they do have some motorcycles in the game and some “toy vehicles”. In general this has a lot of vehicles which are very much wasted on me, because I just crash into the other vehicles because I'm childish and want to play bumper cars.Gameplay: There are three car “classes”, and different stats with each car. Stunt class cars will get you boosts by preforming tricks, Aggression class cars get you boosts by being a jerk (I really like playing Aggression cars and cackling evilly as I push an NPC into the wall), and lastly Speed class cars, which you fill by near misses, upon filling the boost you can preform “burnouts” which let you boost after your boost meter runs out, so in a way you could just keep boosting... as long as you don't crash in between boosts.Like most car games, there are also specific stats on the various vehicles, some cars have high Speed, others have high boost, and still others have high Strength. Speed = you go faster. Boost = you have more boost you can charge up. Strength = your car can take a bigger beating from the competition.Achievements: There are no steam achievements for this game, at this time. However there are plenty of in-game unlockables that you can obtain. It's important to note someday there might be steam achievements, because on the Xbox there are 60 achievements on the core game, + 10 with the various DLC expansions.Price: Burnout Paradise is priced at $19.99, you can easily spend an hour for every dollar spent playing this game, there's a lot to do. That is the theme of Open world games. As I commonly do in my reviews, I suggest you wait for a sale to purchase this game, if you purchase it... I got my copy of the game on a Humblebundle.Before you buy, one final note: There are a number of reviews out there on this game saying that this game has been falsely advertised. I cannot speak from experience because I never played this game anywhere else. You're only getting the core game with the Purchase of “Burnout Paradise: The Ultimate Box”, in other words if you look up DLC for this game, all of that is unavailable. You cannot even purchase the DLC on steam. For die-hard-Burnout Paradise fans, that's a tough knock. So it's worth noting that you're not getting “the Ultimate Box”, you're just getting the core game.Conclusion: To quickly recap: Story – not really a selling point. Gameplay – fun, even if you're not very big on car and/or racing games. Very forgiving when you crash early in the game. Achievements – Nonexistent. Price – Fair, I suggest waiting for a sale. Remember – you're only getting the core game.All in all, this is a fun car game which can be appreciated regardless of how obsessed (or couldn't care less) about cars. I recommend this game for people who enjoy racing games, or want to give a driving game a shot, keep in mind the open world aspect is a big appeal to certain gamers rather then others. (Open world is my favorite)As always, thanks for reading my review.

number of helpful: 16 of 20 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Are you looking for a different racing game, or planning to get into the racing genre? Then this might just be the game for you! Burnout Paradise isn't your usual racing game, but will still supply you with hours of fun!The racing genre has many subcategories, and the burnout franchise might just be an entire subgenre on it's own. You still have the basics like racing of course, but EA has a different look at racing. You can crash into things, crash other racers, make stunts while still aiming for the first place.GameplayThe main concept is still the same. You are in a car, dropped in Paradise city, have fun. The physics aren't too different from other games, but I felt that drifting has been kept to a minimum. Which isn't necessarely a bad thing, especially not in a city full of buildings and other cars.Like I said before, you are able to crash into everything, breakable or unbreakable. Remember however, that it doesn't mean your invincible. At least, not in most events. Fortunately, there are several repair stations around Paradise City so that shouldn't be the biggest of your problems.You start off with a basic car at a junkyard, and the game will teach you several things before you start the journey. However, it does barely to not teach about the controls, which is something you have to find out yourself unfortunately. If you're familiar with racing games, then this won't be any problem for you, but it may be annoying for new players.Each car has 3 stats, being Speed, Boost and Strength. It is up to you to seek the best combination which both fits your driving style and is the most useful in events. Events are scattered all around Paradise City, of which I have a few examples below:Races - I can't make it more obvious. The great thing about Burnout however, is that you decide your own route. That's right, you are not stuck on a set route where you just have to show your skills and prove your the best. Shortcuts and ramps are your best friends in Paradise City.Road Rages - Personally my favorite of the bunch. Your goal is to take out a set amount of cars in a set amount of time.Take overs - This has nothing to do with racing whatsoever, but it is still fun. Think of it as a minigame, where your car is like a ball, trying to hit as many objects as possible to get crash dollars, which are mandatory for completing the event. I will admit that this event gets boring after a while, and you have to do this event a lot if you're seeking completion.When you complete an event, it sometimes occurs that there's a new car racing through the city. You can take it out and add it to your own collection! Also, you get a new car every time you upgrade your license. Your license gets upgraded every time after you have completed a set amount of events.PresentationThe game is still part of the racing genre, but still does many things different from other games in the same genre. Instead of selecting events, you are racing through Burnout Paradise, which is the overworld itself! I won't touch the graphics however. Graphics is something strictly personal to people, so I can't give my opinion on that. For me however, the graphics are pretty good and fitting of the game. You can see far ahead of you and I haven't experienced any lagg or framedrops during my playthroughs of the game.We now have Steam music, but I still want to mention that the music selection in Burnout is pretty good. There is music for everybody, from metal to opera to classic. Of course, there is also the narrator, being the dj of this radio station, who will give you advice during the game.There are a few things I have to mention, that may not be appealing to several people. For example, cars aren't customizable. The only things you can change to your car are the colours. I personally don't mind this but I can understand that other people do.To go online, you are also required to have or creat an EA account. It's not too big of an issue, unless you are strictly against it of course.The final stepsBeating the game isn't too hard. It only requires you to complete events until you got the final license. I would recommend trying to take on as many different events as possible, because otherwise it might become boring/repetitive over time.Completing the game however, turns out to be a more difficult journey. The game does not have Steam Achievements, but there are in-game achievements called Paradise Awards. They are technically the same as Achievements, only that they won't show up on your Steam profile.I myself am not a completionist, but it does bother me that the game handles collectables rather poorly. There are Super Jumps, Billboards to destroy and Fences to drive though. Unfortunately, When you achieve a colletable, it does not show up anywhere on the map for example. You will most likely have find them all by the end of the game, but it's still a nitpick which I can't overlook.ConclusionBurnout is a really fun game that I would recommend to anyone looking for a new fresh experience. People familiar to the racing genre might find a few nitpicks, but may still find a lot of fun here. And while this may be different from most racing games, this may still be a good starting point for newcomers to the genre.While not necessary, it is recommended to play this game with a controller/

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This was one of the original break-em and smash them racing games. My first introduction to the burnout series was Burnout : Revenge for the original xbox. Revenge was action packed and had very smooth game play. This game compared to it's predecessor is good but lacks fluidity and solid core mechanics. I would recommend Flatout Ultimate Carnage over this as it has more mini games, is less of a grind and for me was more engaging. Unlike Flatout, Burnout Paradise let's you explore the open world with some new vehicle types. Paradise city is an open world crash-em-up racer. The gameplay is pretty sound but can have some hiccups here and there regarding fluidity. You may drive around town freely and look and participate any event that is currently available to you. To start events, simply drive up to the event circle and press the gas and brake at the same time. These events come in the forms of Burnout Route/Burnout Ride (specifically for motorcycles) in which you race the clock for modified parts for your car, marked man which you race to a specific point while dodging enemy AI players trying to crash you, road rage mode where players are required to take out a certain amount of cars to proceed, stunt mode where air time, rolls and spins earn you points and finally Road Rules. There are two "modes" to road rules : time and showtime rules. Time is like a time attack whereas showtime requires the player to cause as much havoc to traffic as possible. The main sell point of this game is to do "take-downs", meaning taking out an opposing car. Hitting cars with a good momentum will send them on their way with a nice cinematic crash video effect. Naturally, as you progress through the game, you are able to choose different cars in your garage given you've completed different events and tasks. There will be random race cars sometimes cruising through the streets waiting for you to take them down. There is no real set agenda regarding which car comes first or which car you see. Upon catching up to them taking these newly found cars out, these cars will be added to your garage. If you don't manage to take the car down or don't feel like it, chances are it will appear again (so don't panic)! There are quite a few car frames to choose from such as cars, vans, police cruisers, roadsters, classics, SUV's, F1, motorcycles and supercars. Cars have three criteria/ratings in regards to their performance. The three criterion's are speed, boost rating and strength. Different cars prefer different ways to acquire boost. Some vehicles rely on speed, others rely on aggressiveness to fill their meters while another category relies on stuns. There are other specific boost types but are very particular to a small amount of cars. Some cars have such good performance (I'm talking the special cars you acquire way after) that they do not have boost.   The graphics are actually quite good and some of the crash effects and visuals are really nice to watch. Although be it easy to knock some players out, it is still satisfying to see everything break apart. The sounds are pretty good and do a decent job immersing the player. Car sounds and crashes have a pretty good range and don't sound all the same. The game like I said is nice to play (with different vehicles such as motorcycles) but in my personal opinion is missing that umph factor when hitting opponents. The damage scheme is great, however the impact engine doesn't let you feel how hard you are hitting another car. Not only that, every time you do get a hit off the game sort of stops for a scenematic. I like fluidity; the fact that Flatout gives you a chance to recover whereas Burnout doesn't is up to the gamer to choose the preferred style. For that reason I would have to recommend Flatout Ultimate Carnage over this game. If you like what you see then I recommend it, if you want a racing game with a bit more depth and challenges I'd go for Flatout. It's an average game in my opinion without a speedometer (unlike flatout)!RATING : 7/10 Gameplay B- Story/Campaign B+ Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B- Overall B-

content:
Posted: April 13
												-As a general disclaimer to anyone willing to purchase Burnout Paradise: The Ultimate Box, the game was made for consoles and later ported to the PC. -This version of the game doesn't include *any* of the DLC as they cannot be purchased anymore (The Burnout Store was closed). If you buy the Ultimate Box, you will get all updates that the game has received, including but not only Day and Night cycles and Bikes. Please also note that the major Big Surf Island DLC was never released on the PC by the developers.-Online multiplayer can still be played, but there are barely any players on there.-Without any of the DLC, there's still a good amount of cars in the game to try out (Around 70-80 of them).Leaving that aside, for its price, the game is definitely worth it. You get a game that redefined its genre at the time, and still somehow manages to please till date. The speed and feel is extremely thrilling, and I find myself moving from side to side, even though all I'm technically doing is pressing a few keys. The open world is fantastic and the physics, amusing. Despite the date, even the graphics are phenomenal. Highly recommended even for people who haven't played racing games before (Me).

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												Burnout ParadiseStory - Ok I'm not sure if this is story mode, but I'd count at it. I'll explain what you gotta do in a sec. There are 5 types of events, Races, Marked Man, Stunt Run, Road Rage, and Burning Routes.Races ~ Pretty self explanatory, race with other cars (or one car) to a point on the map. They're not laps, it's just get from one point to the other. A to B.Marked Man ~ Heavily armoured and fast cars are trying to take you down, you have to get to a destination on your map. It's harder than it sounds. I'm pretty good at racing games and I've failed a coulpe times at this.Stunt Run - You get points for each stunt you make, all you gotta do is do enough stunts to pass the score limit.Road Rage - Destroy a number of cars before the timer runs out. This is my favourite one.Burning Route - It's like a race, except you're on a timer and there are no cars racing you. "Well then what's the point of this?" If you beat the time limit, you get a better version of the car you own. They're actually quite fun. 10/10Storyline Length - A long time. Very long. You'll play for days on end.AI - On everything EXCEPT Marked Man, they're a bit weak and slow and dumb. They're still fun to play against, but I'd love a difficulty setting. 7/10Experience - You also get to play on a motorbike, which is amazing. Anyway, around 75 cars to get, and like 3 bikes to get. All the missions are fun, and there are even yellow gates to smash through and billboards to destroy! You can also set a time road rule and showtime record on a road. Play the game and you'll know what I mean. This game is awesome. Enough said. 10/10Graphics - I love them. They're not realistic, but they're not cartoony. They're just as you'd expect a game from a few years back to be. Just amazing. 8/10Sounds / Voice Acting - The radio is just amazing, I'm not even saying that lightly. It has literally one of the best soundtracks of all time. The DJ's voice is nice to listen to, it grabs your attention and the car sounds are beautiful! Some cars have a different "rev" sound, which is amazing. Can't quite believe the amount of detail in this game. 10/10Controls - Ok before you guys start going "OMG WASD AND ARROWS ARENT WORKING ARHFDGNFHGNFHN" lemme tell you the controls.A ~ Move forward.Z ~ Move backwards.Left + Right arrow keys ~ Turn.I don't know why, but I actually very much like it when the controls are layed out like that. 9/10Overall - 9/10 Hands down the best racing game I've ever played it. Finished it so many times in the span of a few years. You'll enjoy it. Buy it! It's marvellous!

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												I'm not a racing pro nor a big fan of racing games, but i tried a few. I want to start this review with pros & cons, but these are just my opinions.Pros:Visuals -- The game is Beautiful --Open world -- I played with a few NFS titles and Street Racing Syndicate, and i dont remember that any of them had a real open world racing, and I mean racing, not freeroam. Yeah, I was waiting for that open world racing, but i must admit, that sometimes its very confusing, when you dont know where the finish line is. --Car Damage -- Yeah!!! I like the slowmo car wrecking :) --And I think thats all of the pros in my opinion. Lets check the cons.Cons:UI -- Dafuq!!! No speedometer, no tachometer... Is this a racing game or what? But atleast it has a Nitro bar... excuse me, a Boost bar --Invisible man -- I know that this is nothing, but this is not Knight Rider... I want a Driver in the driver seat --Manufacturers -- Just avoid this if you wish, but the car and manufacturer names are irritating me --Car customizing -- Correct me if im wrong, but the car customization in this game is equal to zero... or almost zero... you can choose from a few colors and paint your car. Maybe I played a bit too much with NFSU 1-2, NFSMW and NFSC, but in a STREET racing game the lack of car customization makes the game rly boring rly fast. And for me the customization, new parts, etc. count as motivation... so yeah i lost my motivation --Story  -- I know, I know... if I want a story, then I should go and play Skyrim. But even in the NFS titles I mentioned before there were events and there was a main storyline, not so detailed as in an RPG game, but atleast I was motivated, but here... i lost my motivation twice. --Publisher -- EA... do I have to say more? --Ingame Store -- Abandoned --Concluson:I really enjoyed the first few hours in this game, its an eye candy and sadly its only an eye candy, nothing more. Its the second day I play with this game, and its boring as hell. I know that my most pros and cons that I wrote are small things, but  small things can make the game good or bad. In this case in my opinion the game failed to be a Good game. Its beautiful, but not even close to be good.To be honest, if u have the chance to win this game on a giveaway, or get it free, then give it a shot, but dont waste any money on it.

number of helpful: 28 of 49 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Okay so Burnout Paradise is really fun but I feel like it has lots of missed potential. Hear me out.- The open world concept is a really good idea, but it doesn't make a lot of sense to then focus all the attention in 8 points of the world map. You're basically making every other place look uninteresting.- You can pick up events all over the map... Or the city should I say, since the areas outside the city almost have none. That makes the areas outside the city uninteresting. After driving through the roads a couple of times I wouldn't have many reasons to return.- Having everything taking place in the city makes the map feel cramped and hard to navigate through. Burnout is not a game in which I want to go slowly so I don't miss anything.- Good luck exploring a whole city without turn by turn navigation. Nobody wants to open a world map while driving. No, the road signs are not enough.- The events in the city make you leave the city almost all of the time. Which means that if you want to play another event you'll probably need to return to the city, and that feels like a loss of time for the player. You should never make the player feel like their time doesn't matter, especially after rewarding them for clearing an event.- The events start to feel repetitive after a while. Even if there are many types of events, if you are always racing to the same place, it gets kind of boring.- It doesn't matter how high you score in an event since the only thing the game acknowledges is if you passed or not. A rank system would have made the experience a lot more interesting.- The menus don't feel natural at all, especially the d-pad menu. This menu demands your attention while driving (or even while an event takes place), and unless you stop the vehicle there's no way to drive and navigate through the menu without crashing. It doesn't make sense to put the "Restart last event" option in a place like that.- There's no explicit way to exit an event. You have to stop the car. I had to Google this. That is not good design.- The way to start an event leads to many accidental starts. You can't expect me not to push accelerate + brake in a turning point for any other reason than starting an event.- The classical music feels like a bad joke that was funny only the very first time. It doesn't fit in the mood of the rest of the game.- The idea of including different types of cars and adding motorbikes was nice, but poorly executed. It takes way too much time to find a junkyard and then change the vehicle for a certain event, not that it matters anyway because at least for now every vehicle seems to be fit for every kind of event. It makes me wonder why make different types of cars in the first place and not make just one kind. If you are going to make different profiles of playable entities at least give me a reason to use them. Choices should have a meaning in the mechanics, apart from the way the vehicle earns boost.- The respawn algorithm is just awful. Don't respawn me in front of a wall. Don't respawn me in front of a jump.- Takedowns don't feel as rewarding as they used to in other games of the series. Where is Impact Time? Why can't you do multiple takedowns at the same time?- No windowed mode?Don't get me wrong, as I stated earlier this game is really fun. But it could be a lot better and that bothers me.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Serious racing simulator enthusiasts can stop reading, because this isn't the game for you.On the other hand, if you're the kind of person who loves: watching stuff slam into other stuff at 100 miles an hour, vans doing barrel rolls through the air, and the concept of "getting extra points for driving on the wrong side of the road", then this is DEFINATELY the game for you.In Burnout Paradise, you start off with one car. It's okay, a little slow, and just generally "yep, that's a car". You can unlock more cars by encountering them in the large, open-world map, and then RAMMING THEM INTO♥♥♥♥♥♥ Then, go get your new car, and go nuts. There are many kinds of activities to loudly persue while breaking all known rules of the road. Races, "Marked Man" challenges, Stunt Runs, and Burning Routes (which unlock an upgraded version of the vehicle they're associated with). Now, zipping around in singleplayer is fun, and lets you get acclimated with the gorgeous (even this long after release) world of Burnout Paradise. It also lets you get new rides, and so on and so forth. But then you log into Multiplayer, and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥Massive, sprawling, high-speed BRAWLS of ten, twenty, however many cars just roaring along, causing destruction and mayhem wherever they go. Custom challenges, grudge-match crashing, and just general shenanigans are the norm. Think it was hard to nail the landing on a super-jump in singleplayer? Try doing it in multiplayer while four players in large, angry-looking SUVs try to ram you out of the air.In summary: Good for fun, not so good for realism. Great multiplayer potential, but solid Singleplayer. Good price, good graphics, small size on Hard Drive. GREAT soundtrack, excellent open-world map, extreme replayability.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Open world racing from a top notch studio.  So much fun, it still holds up today.  The game itself is great, but "Ultimate"... not so much.  There was more DLC available, but not all of it actually comes with this game, and you can no longer obtain it. :(  Still worth the purchase, though.UPDATE: More of the DLC is now available: the Bonus Vehicle Pack, which includes 4 separate add-ons previously available only on consoles.  You can buy a key for it on Amazon for $10, but as of just recently, you can purchase it straight from Origin for $1.49.  You'll need to register your activation key with Origin first (if you bought the original game here), and then you can get the DLC. Once it's registered on your Origin account, the content should show up in-game, even if you play it from here, as long as you're signed into that Origin account in the game.It's still missing "Cops and Robbers" and "Big Surf Island", the latter of which is a huge disappointment, as it would have added a ton more content.  It's never been officially released for PC, but there is a (perfectly legal) mod out there (still in development) that actually adds most of the content that would have been included in these 2 additions.  Use at your own risk, results may vary, and because I can't post links, you'll have to figure it out from this:  burnouthints dot webs dot com

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Burnout Paradise, oh where to begin... (Controller Review, I've never touched this game with my M/KB)This game is wonderful, from the up-to-date(ish) graphics to its still perfectly functioning engine and controls.You start off as a rookie driver, starting license, starting car... which happens to be a piece of junk.You complete different kind of events from Road Rages to Marked Man, Stunt events and Casual Races where you get to choose your own path because the entire darn island is your track, your paradise.You unlock new cars, which will be roaming around Paradise city and you have to take them down before you own them and get the option to drive them.You get rewarded some new cars instantly when you upgrade your license by completing multiple Events.This rewarding system makes this game in no way possible... "Boring", it makes it beautifully and generously amazing.after a few hours of gameplay you can already feel yourself getting better, see yourself getting better, you can gradually see each new car going faster than the previous one which slowly but surely improves your driving skill, guaranteed no matter how bad you are/used to be in racing games.all in all, this game is a 10/10 would recommend to anyone, fan or not of the Racing Genre.Also, DLC Related: If you own the game on Origin, you can buy the DLC for a $1,70 or something... and this will instantly link it through origin to your EA account in Paradise City.Afterwards, when you run Paradise City through steam and log in to your EA account.. the DLC will be on your game, even on Steam.So if you ever bought the Humble Origin Bundle, use that Origin key because it's still working! I just tried mine 1-6-2016.Otherwise you should buy the game on Origin as well, sorry :(Pros:-Amazing music, loved it.-Rodeo flipped a big♥♥♥♥♥tanky Van sprayed with the Burnout logo, 10/10 -Beautiful graphics.-Camera Angles on crashes/takedowns are great.-Remember DJ Atomika from your childhood PS2 game SSX3? he's back.-Perfect controller support, no flaws whatsoever.-Free roam map, player gets to choose where he/she wants to go, whenever.-70+ vehicles to unlock and choose from.Cons: -You will crash, a lot.-^Deal with it, you scrub.-Just kidding.Actual Cons:-Honestly, I can't say I found any cons, except for the DLC thing (In-game shop has been offline since the dinosaurs went extinct).\Any kind of rating for my review would be kindly appreciated!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												For Burnout Racers and players who enjoy playing racing games, this is a game that you will like. It features a big city to cruise around, while being able to smash billboards, security gates, and show off your car in super jumps (if you can find them). The showtime feature brings you into crash mode, which allows you to cause as much damage as possible. It has 120 events for you to complete in Single Player, unlocking more cars as you progress through the game and upgrading to the Burnout Licence. I would recommend this game for racers who enjoy racing games!

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Probably still my favourite ever driving game, perhaps tied with Burnout Revenge. The PC port works and plays wonderfully, albeit with a slightly broken store now (you don't get the Toys, Legends cars etc and they're unavailable permanently).But the game hasn't aged a bit in seven years. It's got tight, fantastic driving controls, the missions are fun, and the free-form world, while it takes a bit of getting used to, is fun to explore and crafted incredibly with beautiful attention to detail on shortcuts, different areas etc. As a fan of collecting stuff in games as well, this game totally appeals to me - forget the events when I can go around smashing through all the shortcut gates, billboards, and jumps in the world while taking in the sights.For five quid, this is a steal. I paid £40 for it originally and have had so much enjoyment out of it I still think I got a bargain.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
I would happily pay MORE for this game, thats how good it is.Burnout: Paradise is probably still one of the best driving games there is out there. The graphics aren't exactly incredible, but for the date of it's release, they were the♥♥♥♥♥♥ I bought this game when it came out on the PS3, and I decided to buy it for the nostalgia, and I got exactly that! It's an incredible game with literal weeks of entertainment. Hundreds of races/missions and SO many different cars to unlock (including some DLC cars). I would happily pay £30 for this game, THAT'S how good it is. Even though the game being old, there are still multiplayer servers running, which I find really great of EA! EA is not a good company, lets be honest. But this game is actually one of their best ones. I really don't think there is any modern driving game out there which could match up to the standards of Burnout: Paradise. Driving games these days are all so samey, with no real FUN to the game. So what if the game doesn't have 4K quality graphics? I would rather play an average looking game with incredible content than a 4K game with literally no fun aspects whatsoever.10/10 - "Best driving game out there, despite the age of the game."

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2011
												This game is still the best racing game available to the public, in my opinion. Criterion Games may be making the NFS series now, but they can't seem to replicate the awesome intensity of this game, not by a long shot.Paradise City is a big open box of fun, where whatever route you want to take to get to the finish line, is up to you.None of this horsing around with the side routes you aren't allowed on, if there's a path, it goes somewhere, and it's just waiting for you to find out just where that is.Burnout: Paradise follows a single, simple racing law...If you're not in first. Get there.If you're in first, stay there.This game doesn't bother you with a clunky HUD and a speedometer, letting you know that you're traveling faster than everyone else, from last place. There's no rear-view mirror, blocking your view of what dangers might lie before you.You have one objective, win the race. And staring at your speedometer, watching the soccer moms in the mirror won't help you obtain that objective in the least.Race.Race Faster.Win.What a fantastic game.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												I am not a fan of racing games. I didn't like Need for Speed, Forza or Project Gotham but i can honestly say that Burnout Paradise is one of my alltime favourite games. Pro's:Beautiful graphicsRuns well on low end PC'sThe way of unlocking cars by running them off the roadAn excellent blend of licensed songs (mainly rock based) and studio made onesintense racesLoads of hidden routes and a amazing hidden stunt park (airfield)The slow Motion crash scenes never get old Cons:Their are really only 5 racing destinationsMore experienced Racers than me might find the Race gamemode to easyThe marked man cars tend not to follow you through hidden routesTakedown gamemode is easy but really funConclusion:If you are a hardcore racing gamer then this game is probably not for you. If you are someone that is not a fan of racing games then this game will suffice for 8 Hours+ of gametime.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Of all the racing games I've ever owned, I have to say this one has been the most fun!It feels like the game Need For Speed: Most Wanted really wanted to be but just didn't quite hit the mark.  It's typical Burnout: silly, crazy fun with lots of different race modes in a gorgeous open-world.  Unlock better cars at junkyards, learn bigger and better stunts, beat the fastest record for a myriad set of roads or survive brutal races where you must smash a given number of cars out of the race.  For those who find bikes more fun, this is two games in one!  You can start the game in car or motorbike mode instead, with just as many stunts and unlocks to achieve.This game is also fun for people who don't generally enjoy racing sims.  It's very much arcade-style yet car handling is great with a variety of camera modes to choose from.  The AI is really well made (no rubber-banding or artificial 'cheating' that AI opponents in other games can display).  The difficulty level increases gradually and at the right pace.  It's all enormous fun, light-hearted yet challenging in all the right places.The only problem I've experienced with the game is getting my G27 Logitech Wheel working nicely with it.  People can and do have success, but my wheel has a continuous, strong pull to the left in this game which I cannot resolve.  Your success might vary, and this article[solidlystated.com] (http://solidlystated.com/software/logitech-g27-burnout-paradise/) is essential reading to get your wheel recognised and configured correctly.  Alas, my wheel pull was too much so I stick to a very old and loved Microsoft Sidewinder stick or my XB360 gamepad - still great fun!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
TL;DR - Worth it for short-term smash-things-up fun (if you're willing to put up with the HORRENDOUS menu screens and EA cramming their DRM and EA-Account stuff down your throat forever), but it gets repetitive very quickly; don't buy if you want to immerse yourself in a new world - buy if you want to drive fast and crash into things for fun.After installing the game, it will take you about half an hour to get past all of the EA login crap for the first time.  After that (and after you get used to the incredibly cheeky way that they swap the 'okay' and 'visit store' buttons all the time), you're confronted with an unskippable cutscene introducing you to Paradise City by the one female presence in the game; speaking in (what is supposed to be) a seductive voice whilst saying stuff like "here's the observatory".  It's ridiculous and cringe-worthy, and pretty much sums up EA's attitude towards women here.Once you finally start playing, it's pretty much all good fun.  You can free drive around until you're in the mood to start a race by stopping at the traffic lights, and then you're dropped into either a A->B sprint, a 'takedown' contest where you've got to smash up as many cars as possible, the 'wanted man' event where two cars are trying to take you down whilst you try to get from A->B (my favourite), and finally the 'stunt' mission where you've got to jump and spin and do stuff to hit your target score.  After an ever-increasing number of these events, you unlock a new car - until there's no more missions left - at which point, I guess, you just free roam.It's fun, but very repetitive, and I found myself having the most fun just by seeing how long I could go without crashing, and believe me- it's harder than it sounds.  This isn't a game that will entertain you for all that long; you'll have to make your own entertainment, so buy at the correct price-point accordingly.Definitely not a wholehearted recommendation, but it's okay.  Pros outweigh the cons.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												An awesome game gifted to me by a friend of mine!This game is not your traditional press-fwd-arrow-and-win-racer, because tracks for the races are not scripted and it is an open-world race. You have to know the map like the back of your hand, or constantly open the map menu to draw an imaginary track for your competition, which can get absurdly annoying while you are flying against the oncoming traffic.As I mentioned traffic- this game has somehow too much of it. I know it is a racing game, but regarding the fact that tracks are not scripted, you can crash your car each 4 seconds of a race because of a missed turn or because of too much traffic.At the beginning it is all ok, because the cars that you own are not so fast- you can predict your turns more easily and pass by the traffic, but later on it gets absurdly hard to get to the first place because of the high speeds.Overall a good racing game that is not so hardware-demanding, brings a lot of fun, but in order to "feel" that fun, you need to invest in a lot of time studying the city, the shortcuts, jumps etc.I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 19
												Burnout Paradise. A good installment for the series without a doubt. Is it as good as Burnout 3 Takedown was ? Obviously not. But that's not fair since Burnout 3 was close to perfect. Is it as good as the others ? Hmmm. Debates will arise.The impression of speed is here, as good as ever. A lot of cars to unlock, drive, each of them handling differently and adpated to different situations, races, goals. A large map, with the diversity you would expect from a good game. Lots of content, collectibles, street records to set... Multiplayer ! A good one ! Still plenty of people to play with, extremely easy to initiate a race while in the world, or just hang around with friends doing stunts and flips.Then why the debates ? In what way is it different from the other installments ? One word : Open world.Yes, open world. Is it a bad open world ? No. Does it create any problems ? Not really. Then why was it not unanimous ? Basically because it's not the usual Burnout formula that we have learned to love and expect. Small issues appear with that formula. The races, as a result, sometimes seem too similar as you'll often take the same paths to get to one part of the map. You can also take a wrong turn with a small misread of the map or after a takedown, and end up losing the race just because going back takes way too long. You also have to know the map like the back of your hand if you want to win any race online. This is pretty much the only issue with the game.It IS a great game. It feels amazing and is a nice addition to the series that attempts new things while keeping the amazing basics every fan loves. It is definitely worth the buy, for any fan of racing games.Play this while we wait for the next one, you won't be disappointed !

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Well, let me start by saying there's nothing Ultimate about this Ultimate Box. EA being the scumbags they are, have shut down the PC store long time ago. So in short at start we don't have the DLC cars and bikes, plus the Big Surf Island update. But worry not, since on PC there is always a way, being the free platform. By googling Vanity pack and "Unlocking Burnout Paradise DLC" once can obtain them. Worry not it will not void anything, plus I think it is fair way of dealing with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s from EA.Anyway onto the game.Set in Paradise City, BP is open world carmageddon with various vehicles all of them which resemble well known brands from "our" world. This way Criterion have carte blanche to do whatever they want to the cars, including showing you the most twisted and masochist way of wrecking them. Being car in BP ain't easy.We have open world here and nods with different types of races, the usual stuff any Burnout veteran knows: Race, Road Rage and few new like Stunt Run, where you need to jump trough hoops, ramps, edges to bring up the score. The more stylish stunts the more points. Of course the more you play the more you unlock so exploration is rewarded, especially when you can find the various gas stations(boost refill), paint garages (so you can unlock all colors of the car) etc. helpful points of interest.To be hones I was hoping to be something like Revenge and Takedown since I love the track designs there. I've seen all of Paradise and I already miss the alps from Takedown or the Autumn Peak from Revenge. Still Paradise is fun place to be with various stuff and conveniently placed jumping ramps. You have half decent soundtrack but you can always start your trusty mp3 application and spin some tunes if you want.Navigation trough Paradise city is stupid and annoying. You have compass over your head, who most of the times points the right way and god awful mini map which is static and I looked trough the menus and didn't find where I can turn rotation on, since when you are in dynamic races you can mistake your way fairly easy. Yeah sure, the incoming street names blink when you have to make a turn, but try doing that when you jet trough with over 250 km/h(♥♥♥♥ Imperial) trying to do 90 degrees turn. Sometimes it works, sometimes a big♥♥♥♥♥crash occurs with all of the racers. In the end I bough the game for 1.50 euro so no big complains but I sure wouldn't buy it at retail price, especially with EA's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥gery ways pack behind it.A solid 7.5/10, fun game, oh and multiplayer is still alive.TL;DR:+ Same old fast paced mad racing speed+ Awesome car designs + Nice looking graphics+ Not locked on 30fps- EA's doucebagging ways: no way to obtain DLC trough the official store, since it's shut down- Big Surf Island is not in this, so nothing that "Ultimate" about it- No crashbreaker, the good old slow - mo where you can control your wrecked car, and score "Aftertouch", instead we have some half -♥♥♥♥♥♥♥crash mode you can start at any point when you wreck... No that awesome as in Burnout 3 and Revenge- No really breath taking tracks like Alpines form B3 or Autumn Peak in Revenge- So - so soundtrack - Dumb and annoying navigation- No Crash Events

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												A fun smash 'em up type racing game. It's a few years old but it holds up well and has decent graphics. You can have fun no matter what style you prefer: road racing, stunt runs, crashing other cars and avoiding other cars crashing into you are all options. You will have to do at least a few races that are different from your favourite to progress in the game. There are also a bunch of discoverable things and jumps to keep you busy. Sadly the expansion packs aren't available because the Criterion store closed fairly soon after the game was released, although I understand Amazon has it for US customers only. It's a pity because I would really like to try out some of the cars in the expansions. All in all a good and fun game but don't expect any patches or bug fixes in the future.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I absolutely love this game, Nice open-world experience, fantastic graphics, nice idea on how to unlock new cars and bikes. it's a great game. It's nice to see a game released where you can drive around exploring an open area, some games have that but they're not as fun to explore as Burnout Paradise. if you've played Burnout Revenge, and you remembered all 8 of the maps, this game combines all 8 of those maps from Burnout Revenge into one huge area you can explore. there's only one thing that makes it a little disappointing: there's orchestra music. I'm a huge fan of the burnout series and this is the first burnout game that has orchestra music. That's not burnout, Burnout's music is mainly techno, dance, or rock music. It's not all orchestra music, there is some techno, dance, and rock music in this game,  so it's not all that bad.Graphics: beautiful, this game runs great on my PC, no lag at all, graphics at high-resolution look great, better than on the console.[my PC specs are in my showcase box description]Gameplay: smooth driving mechanic, very fun to drift around curve's and earn points in stunt events. It's nice to see interest points, like a repair shop where you can repair your car, a gas station where you can refill your boost, and places to paint your car even though the paint is selected for you at random. Also, some goals set out in the open world, like short cuts, Burnout Paradise bild boards you can break, and ramps where you can get high air jumps. which is a very cool idea if you're just exploring paradise city you can complete those tasks while your doing it. One thing it does need for the mechanic is a spedometer, that's about it. I'm going to score this game a 9/10, Best open-world racing game I've played yet. I'm a huge fan of the burnout series and I'm very happy that this game to be in the burnout series.

Posted: August 13, 2014
												Even if it's a 2008 game,Burnout Paradise is still a great game to play.A crystal for racing games,this game will totally be worth it's price.Let's see why.GAMEPLAY: Despite lacking a story like the other Burnout games,this game proved to be very fun and addictive to play even without one.The races are extremely fun,especially Road Rage.Watching cars smashing to pieces really makes you want to play Road Rages over,over,and over,and one more thing: OVER,again.Also Marked Man,Stunts and Races.GRAPHICS: Criterion Games worked really well on the graphics,and effects.The graphics are exceptional for a 2008 game.It's very well detailed in my opinion.The effects,oh well.GREAT.Absolutely great.The way your vehicle smashes in another car and starts rolling down the road,losing tires and parts starting to twist and even FALL off,or even when some cars transform into cans when you smash into a wall.Multiplayer: The multiplayer starts from tun to extremely fun when playing with friends.Environment: Paradise City is HUGE.So you have a lot of zones to explore,plus billboards and fences to smash down.My final rating for Burnout Paradise,is 9/10.It's totally,worth it.GO AND BUY IT.Now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												When people say that Burnout Paradise was a high point in the last generation (as of 2014) of racing games, it's not hyperbole or due to a large amount of cash. It's because it's that good.The gameplay is still extremely fun by today's standards, and so are the graphics. There is just so much to find in the city, be it races, parking garages, Super Jump ramps, drive-throughs and those pesky fences and billboards. Be prepared to spend hours trying to beat your friends' Road Rule scores as well.The motorcycles are certainly a welcome addition to the game, adding a whole new learning experience to the gameplay due to the different manner bikes and cars behave. If only they had released the other DLC on PC or at least bothered keeping the Burnout Store online...If you ever have to limit youself to just one arcade racing game, make it this one.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2012
												It's an amazingly good racing game, horribly marred by EA's terrible choices regarding DLC.A third of the console versions' DLC is included in the "Ultimate Box" version.A third of the console versions' DLC was never brought to PC at all, including a whole new island full of challenges and things to do, which is a pretty significant chunk of game.And a third of the DLC is in the game, but locked until you buy it from the in-game shop wityh real money. But EA shut the shop down only a few months after release. So despite those bits of DLC being in the game, you can never unlock them (through any legitimate means) because EA won't even sell them to you anymore.I still recommend it, with reservations, but I recommend the console versions even more if they're an option. Or you can just stay away and not encourage EA to behave like this, but they're not going to notice or care anyway, so... your call there.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												video game (feat. video & aggro lavine's boyfrend song)good physics but hard to appreciate. they stuck with the idea of never teleporting the player so objectives are generally easy enough to not need to retry. a LOT of time will be spent watching cars crash into things in ultra-slowmo. can't turn it off even though multiplayer disables it.the map is nicely designed but the graphics dont do it any favors. even important parts of the road blend into the unsaturated scenery. there's a few hundred things to jump and crash into for completionists. the whole area is unlocked from the start and never changes so it does get stale.progression feels slow and repetitive: complete # objectives, reset map with slightly more difficult AI, rinse and repeat. unlocking cars is the main reason to continue; they're decently varied and each with an upgraded version to get.dont forget the EA-mandatory condescending announcer guy telling you how to press a button, and unskippable opening logos. also audio options dont take effect until you gain control of your car so i hope you like ACDC's viridian city blaring each time you open it.it's a game with a lot of wasted potential but i found myself pouring hours into it anyway so idk who even reads these things im gayps. dont play online with a webcam plugged in

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												**REVIEW CHANGED FROM NEGATIVE TO POSITIVE** - See Edit for detailsI'm torn. Giving this a negative review is something that hurts me a lot, because I really love this game and I have done for years. I get annoyed when people start their reviews like this, but hear me out. This game is fantastic. I first played it back when it first came out on the old 360, and it was a blast to pick up and play with my friends. The game is great and I had unlocked every car in the game. The driving is more than solid, and holds up well today. Got a great soundtrack, a lot of cars and an interesting world to play around in.So why the negative review for the PC version? In fact, the negative review isn't for the game itself, it's because the DLC is not available on PC any more, at least on the Steam version. This is a huge shame because the DLC has some of my favourite parts of the game, especially the toy cars pack and, in this case, the time savers pack. Of course, if this doesn't bother you, please disregard the negativity. It's a very good game, especially so with friends. If you don't want the DLC then consider this review a shining endorsement! I LOVE this game! But if you want my advice? Just don't get the Steam version. Get it on Origin instead as you can at least get the bonus vehicle DLC pack.Edit: This review wasn't really clear when I first wrote it, so I'm making some quick corrections. The game is good, don't get me wrong. I guess the biggest contributor to the issue is that the game just doesn't have any support on Steam any more, hence why I suggested getting the game on Origin instead as some DLC is still available. I am aware Criterion have moved on from this and aren't supporing it any more at all, but I don't expect them to continue supporting a game this old anyway. I've changed the review to a positive one after realising my mistakes (thanks for bringing me up on it, Illimitus). The game is great, I really want to sing it's praises, but if you want the DLC Steam isn't the place to do it. If you want a good game without DLC, this is absolutely worth a purchase. Apologies for a misleading negative review, any future reviews will not be made just before going to bed on a late night :)

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												A fun smash 'em up type racing game. It's a few years old but it holds up well and has decent graphics. You can have fun no matter what style you prefer: road racing, stunt runs, crashing other cars and avoiding other cars crashing into you are all options. You will have to do at least a few races that are different from your favourite to progress in the game. There are also a bunch of discoverable things and jumps to keep you busy. Sadly the expansion packs aren't available because the Criterion store closed fairly soon after the game was released, although I understand Amazon has it for US customers only. It's a pity because I would really like to try out some of the cars in the expansions. All in all a good and fun game but don't expect any patches or bug fixes in the future.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												This is one of if not the best racing game that I have ever played! Almost everything is spot on, and there are very few annoyances. The graphics, gameplay, music, and the design of paradise city are fantastic! the city, the cars, and everything else are very well detailed. The gameplay is tight, esponsive, and the controls feel perfect for this game (if you're using a controller). Almost all of the music fits very well into the world and atmosphere that Criterion has made, but I can't say that the music is great (I think it is) because that's all up to youand your personal taste. And Paradise City is a very well crafted open world that is a ton of fun to explore full of seceret areas and shortcuts that help you win challenges! the only major negative that I have is that you sometimes feel like you cant avoid a crash. Mainly because you sometimes cant see a car, wall, pillar, ect coming until it's too late. That can get pretty annoying, but it doesn't happen all that much. Overall, Burnout Paradise is a very well crafted skill based racer that doesn't hold your hand, but never feels very unfair with great physics, world design, controlls, fitting music, and graphics. I deffinatley reccomend this game to all who want to try it, or are even just slightly interested in it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The best 10 bucks (50% Sale) I have ever spent. While it may only say around 100 hours on my account, I have spent at least double this on offline mode and am just blown away by this game.PROS: - Great physics (apart from poles, boost and barrel rolls) - Massive open world that takes ages to fully explore - Super jumps, billboards, smash gates & street times to find and beat - Absolutely unbeatable graphics (including time of day) for a car-racing game - Change of environment from downtown, to harbour, to beachfront and lakefront to mountainous countrysideCONS: - Online play seriously flawed - "Driveaways"impede race flow - Occasionally Windows 8.1 Computer freezes upon tabbing in (about 1 in 5 chance)Overall though this is a fantastic game in which the pros greatly outweigh the cons and I give it a rating of 9.5/10 flying, crashing and speeding cars through a massive city.

												This is a mixed review, I like the Burnout series a lot, and this one is very good, but the fact that is named "The Ultimate Box" is what doesn´t check.The denominative Ultimate Box is just bait so you think you are gaining all the content from the Console version, but that´s not gonna happen, the content given was a free update in Console versions (Day-Night cycle, the Bikes, the weather) and the things you would expect (The Legendary Cars, the Toy Cars, the extra cities) are nowhere to be seen, not even as a DLC purchase.Don´t get me wrong, the game is good for those who love a non realistic racing game, and for people like myself who are more fighters than drivers, with a lot of events in every intersection...if you drive a car, if you drive a bike the only thing you get is Burning Route or Burning Route, no more.To call this "ultimate" is a joke, but if you see this game on a sale and like arcade style racing games, you´ll feel that the purchase was good, otherwise, just pass without seeing.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Summary: There's lots of stuff to do. If you like racing games, you'll like this one. It's non-stop addictive. One of EA's last good games.After picking it up with the EA Humble Bundle last year, I couldn't stop. There was just so much to do. You start smashing fences for a while and suddenly, a billboard comes into your vision. That billboard's going down. Get some air, bam, full boost, billboard down. So you boost around the city, smashing more fences, looking for those sick blue cone jumps, and soon you unlock some sort of trophy-award type thing. What is this? Searching through the arguably worst menu in history, I find the list of awards. The award you just got is about smashing something like 200 or 300 fences, and you discover that there are more awards! Some for jumps, some for takedowns, some for online things which EA really sucks at, and BILLBOARDS. You look around the map for billboards. Some you can't reach, and you have to figure a way to get to it. After defeating the evil red billboards, beat up all the yellow fences, you come home victorious to the junk yard.Then you start your first race.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Even though Burnout Paradise has been around for over 6 years, it still holds it's own as one of the best racing games in the 360/PS3 generation and beyond. The open world environment mixed with the franchise's classic, chaotic crash system makes for some brilliant fun. The graphics, whilst obviously not flashy by today's standards, still look nice and pretty, plus the smooth framerate than never drops below 60 (on my pc at least) make for some easily enjoyable gaming.There's still multiplayer available, and often when I'm hosting a session with some friends, we get quite a few random players joining the fun.Overall, a great racing game, if you love cars, this is one for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												I'd say that, for a PC Racing Game, this is pretty good... but not perfect.For the good, i will say the controls work pretty well with both Keyboard and Gamepad. Of course, the gamepad works a bit better, but it's one of the few PC racing games i can say i'd actually play with the keyboard.Secondly, the open world is fantastic. It's really large, open to exploration, and just damn fun to drive around in. And finally, all the cars feel unique. Even the clones of the same car, such as the Customs, still feel really good, even different compared to the regular version.But it does have some problems.Not gonna complain about the dlc, but what i will complain about, is the CRASHING. I don't mean Car Crashing, i mean the Game Crashing. It happens randomly, and there are no signs it is going to happen, just one second you're happily driving along, the next, the game crashes. And it happens ALL THE DAMN TIME.Secondly, while it looks great, there are some texture quality problems at times. That's all i'll say about it.I personally can say that i have enjoyed this game quite a good bit, but it's not without faults. I'd reccommend buying it if you have the spare money.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												If you like speeding through cities, dodge traffic and ram your opponents into walls (or the aforementioned traffic), then this game is for you.Featuring an open city, a variety of cars and events, a so-so soundtrack and the never ending joy of bashing opponents to smithereens, Burnout Paradise offers arcade racing fans a treat.If you want to crash into some human enemies, go online and partake in pretty much everything you did in singleplayer!What I'm enjoying most online, though, are the co-op events, where the players unite (more or less) to achieve a common goal, like managing to get to a certain place or do barrel rolls over each other.It's a bit sad that Paradise may be the first and last Burnout making it to PC, as Criterion (and especially EA) seems more focused on Need for Speed. What's also sad is that one of the bigger DLCs never made it to PC: Big Surf Island, which not only includes a whole new are to explore, but also new game modes and cars.But rejoice as modders try to bring exactly that to the PC! It's already playable, although it's still missing a lot of stuff, including singleplayer events, traffic and game modes, but you can explore Big Surf Island, drive a lot of new cars (including whatever cruises through Paradise) and partake in online events!It's called the "Vanity Pack". Go and get it. Seriously.And while we're at DLC: The in-game store has been shut down a long time ago, but you can still get the Legendary Cars, Toy Cars and the Boost Specials from retailers like Amazon.All in all a fantastic game. Get it!

												DISCLAIMER!!!!!!! This DOES NOT include any DLC despite what the title says.I have been a huge fan of the entire Burnout series from day one it is an amazing arcade style game with a ton of different races and modes.Burnout Paradise is by far the most different of them all, think of it as Need for Speed (Carbon/Most wanted) and Burnout had a baby this is that baby unlike other Burnout games when you finish a race the game doesnt go back to any menus or anything it puts ou back into an open world where you can drive around doing whatever you want until you decide to race again which i always loved in the Need for Speed games that had it.But like I said this is not the ultimate box so if you are buying it expecting DLC then just stay away but it is the base Burnout Paradise game which is an amazing game by itself idk if the online modes work or not I dont mess with those but the party play is fun if you have friends over and want to play each other.The soundtrack like all other burnout games is awesome and the world and cars are beautiful this one really shows the damage done to your car better than ever before and the slow motion crash cam is great.I recomend it if you are ok with not having the DLC I suggest getting it on sale though but thats a given with any and all games to me.
