number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This is a good racing game.But instead of just racing, you can also take down your enemies, easily the thing that sets the game series Burnout apart from others. And it's very fun. Another unusual thing is that, while you're racing (or are playing the other modes), there are no arrows to guide you, no boundries. You must rely on your mini-map and / or compass to get to the finishing line. The game has a massive open world with over four hundred shortcuts that you can learn in order to get to the finishing line quicker than the others can. There are also some other "collectibles". You also find events (Racing, Marked Man, Road Rage...) only by exploring the map. The main goal of the game is to get a Burnout Driving License, which you can only get by winning the aforementioned events. You get cars every time you upgrade your license, and when you shut down certain cars.The game also has an online mode, where you can play the same events that you can on singleplayer, but with actual people. Sadly, Race is the only properly made event, as the other ones really haven't had much love given to them. When you're not doing an event in multiplayer, you're on freeburn, where you try beating other people's records (no. of barrel rolls, air distance, etc.). It's quite fun, even if it has its flaws.Now, let's talk about the port: it's bad. The online mode doesn't even have a chat. You can only communicate with other people with voice chat. The menus are really odd too. The optimization is alright. I do have some FPS drops in areas with lots of cars and action, but you can kinda blame it on my PC (although I expected it to perform a bit better regardless). The fast menu is also impossible to access unless you have a controller, which is a problem because that's the menu that allows you to change teams in certain multiplayer events such as Road Rage.Overall, it's a good game. And it's cheap. You don't really need a controller, the keyboard works just fine. It has its flaws, but overall you should get it if you're a fan of racing. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												This game is getting older as we speak. The game is a classic and is really the best Burnout game in the series, I love this game personally and can play it for hours with its multiple missions and many different cars. The cars in this game... Well I love them really, starting the cars driving them at high speeds through the city and the hills. There are many DLCs ,which you know I hate, but there is a definate way to bypass that. The cars are all interesting and really fun to drive, the handling is very easy and you can definatley feel the freedom when you're driving.Firstly the cars in this are awesome! You can get many styles of cars such as: Rage, stunt, street and that wierd turbo thing that only lets you recharge... The entire car system has many different styles of driving, the cars can be stock or the upgraded unlocked version of the original car. You can get mini cars, police cars and many more random types of new cars which can only be found on the origin store. The DLC for paradise island is only avalible for the console versions of this game but you can mod it into the game which adds buggys and a whole new island. The entire games map is massive compared to new games and its nicley detailed, the whole thing has events placed "at every intersection" as explained in the first part of the game which is true! Events on every intersection which can be played again but only to beat your score.The map concludes of beaches, mountains and city scapes with loads of driving to do. I had some technical problems with the game trying to set up multiplayer, EA actually sent me a copy onto my Origin account which then worked. The games multiplayer consists of free drive, races, stunt runs and free races (which is where you set up your own races for your friends). I like playing with my friends because you can have a lot of fun seeing who can get the biggest air alltogether in a certain place or just driving for fun. Multiplayer does have a negative side to it though, its very anoying to setup with multiple game platforms Steam/Origin but I was the only one with this problem.The game does have DLC but noone wants to pay for that so some nice modding community have recreated Paradise Island from the Xbox and Playstation games, the mod also allows you to change cars at random points and adds all of the DLC without EA coming to rip your wallet apart. The DLC is quite fun and you can have lots of random moments with your friends. The mod also allows you to change to any citizen car with any paint scheme which is a nice feature.Only problems that I had. On a Windows 7 Computer it worked fine for a series of time, it would crash ocasionally but that might of been because of my older setup. The game works well with old and new Windows but I had some problems with a Win10 machine, but my friends computer (WIN8) worked fine. I was trying to get the game running with two monitors but then I realised I my older setup was screen center to left which for some reason broke burnout completley but when I disconnected it, the game ran smoothly.You can have hours of fun on any burnout game but especially this one with its free world and ability to choose to do missions when you want to. So I recommend buying this, but remember to play it with friends because it is extremely fun messing around with some areas!

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												In Paradise City, there was a box. Nobody knew what was is in it, nobody was ever able to open it. It had strange letters etched into it, letters which kept the mystery surrounding this box, nicknamed the "Ultimate Box", going for years. What are these letters, you may ask? DLC.In February 5th of 2009, humanity discovered a way to open this box. Simply by inserting money from your wallet or credit card into it's keyhole, for the first time people were able to do something nobody could ever do before; Play Burnout Paradise on the PC. With motorcycles. Following these events, video game megacorporation Electronic Arts claimed ownership of the Ultimate Box and began monopolizing it. However, if you are content with giving your money to the military industrial complex, take out your credit card and get ready to do something absolutely mind-bending. Get ready to play a pretty fun open-world driving game on your very own personal computational device. In 2400p. 120fps. Twin Titan Blacks SLI. Overclocked Pentium 3. Anime mods optional.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2010
												I think in raw fun factor, this one is in my top spot for racing games. Burnout's physics are tuned for bumping and crashing and the game does everything it can to encourage this so it can show off its very impressive car deformation system. This isn't a realistic racing sim. But it is a totally bad♥♥♥♥♥ visually stunning crashing sim.The multiplayer is quite fun if you have a good host. The game world is one huge sandbox map. The host picks from any of the single player modes, and a large variety of specific stunt missions.This is an obvious console port, but aside from the awkward menu system and defaulting the microphone to on (as many console ports do), it plays great on the PC (as long as you have a controller).A word of warning: if you don't have a good sense of navigation, you may find it a bit difficult to choose the optimal paths for a given race, especially if you're ahead of the pack, because the game does not do a very good job helping you out in this respect.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This is a good racing game.But instead of just racing, you can also take down your enemies, easily the thing that sets the game series Burnout apart from others. And it's very fun. Another unusual thing is that, while you're racing (or are playing the other modes), there are no arrows to guide you, no boundries. You must rely on your mini-map and / or compass to get to the finishing line. The game has a massive open world with over four hundred shortcuts that you can learn in order to get to the finishing line quicker than the others can. There are also some other "collectibles". You also find events (Racing, Marked Man, Road Rage...) only by exploring the map. The main goal of the game is to get a Burnout Driving License, which you can only get by winning the aforementioned events. You get cars every time you upgrade your license, and when you shut down certain cars.The game also has an online mode, where you can play the same events that you can on singleplayer, but with actual people. Sadly, Race is the only properly made event, as the other ones really haven't had much love given to them. When you're not doing an event in multiplayer, you're on freeburn, where you try beating other people's records (no. of barrel rolls, air distance, etc.). It's quite fun, even if it has its flaws.Now, let's talk about the port: it's bad. The online mode doesn't even have a chat. You can only communicate with other people with voice chat. The menus are really odd too. The optimization is alright. I do have some FPS drops in areas with lots of cars and action, but you can kinda blame it on my PC (although I expected it to perform a bit better regardless). The fast menu is also impossible to access unless you have a controller, which is a problem because that's the menu that allows you to change teams in certain multiplayer events such as Road Rage.Overall, it's a good game. And it's cheap. You don't really need a controller, the keyboard works just fine. It has its flaws, but overall you should get it if you're a fan of racing. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I'd say this game is closer to being a Tony Hawk-style "stunt game" than it is to being a racing game. Sure, there are races, but there are also challenges based on doing sick flips off of broken parts of bridges as well as ones based on seeing if your car can beat up the other cars. The world that the game takes place in is also very nice; they basically mashed a bunch of cities and settings together into one city specifically designed for racing (though sometimes it's eerie how despite it being a large city, there are 0 pedestrians or otherwise any signs of life apart from empty, self-driving cars), and it works great. And despite this game being relatively old, it still looks great, and the great news is that it still works! Several other old games are unplayable now because of DRM-related issues, and this game is not one of those games (though "DLC Island" is extinct now)This game has a few flaws though. If you're a "purist", this game might upset you since everything feels very arcade-y (for me this was a plus though). Second, some stuff like the aforementioned "DLC Island" is no longer accessible (at least as far as I know) due to DRM shenanigans, so if you're one of those people who boycotts games that suffered from DRM, this might be bad news for you, though having said that the game works fine even with DRM shooting it in the foot slightly (and hey, if you were expecting any better from EA, then... yeah). The in-game announcer DJ Atomika is also annoying, but it's not anything that would completely ruin a game IMO.Overall, I'd say this game is a good buy. I got it in a Humble Bundle many years ago, and it has ended up becoming my all-time favorite racing game, so there's that. (also sorry in advance if this review reads weird, I was a bit tired when I wrote it)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												This game is getting older as we speak. The game is a classic and is really the best Burnout game in the series, I love this game personally and can play it for hours with its multiple missions and many different cars. The cars in this game... Well I love them really, starting the cars driving them at high speeds through the city and the hills. There are many DLCs ,which you know I hate, but there is a definate way to bypass that. The cars are all interesting and really fun to drive, the handling is very easy and you can definatley feel the freedom when you're driving.Firstly the cars in this are awesome! You can get many styles of cars such as: Rage, stunt, street and that wierd turbo thing that only lets you recharge... The entire car system has many different styles of driving, the cars can be stock or the upgraded unlocked version of the original car. You can get mini cars, police cars and many more random types of new cars which can only be found on the origin store. The DLC for paradise island is only avalible for the console versions of this game but you can mod it into the game which adds buggys and a whole new island. The entire games map is massive compared to new games and its nicley detailed, the whole thing has events placed "at every intersection" as explained in the first part of the game which is true! Events on every intersection which can be played again but only to beat your score.The map concludes of beaches, mountains and city scapes with loads of driving to do. I had some technical problems with the game trying to set up multiplayer, EA actually sent me a copy onto my Origin account which then worked. The games multiplayer consists of free drive, races, stunt runs and free races (which is where you set up your own races for your friends). I like playing with my friends because you can have a lot of fun seeing who can get the biggest air alltogether in a certain place or just driving for fun. Multiplayer does have a negative side to it though, its very anoying to setup with multiple game platforms Steam/Origin but I was the only one with this problem.The game does have DLC but noone wants to pay for that so some nice modding community have recreated Paradise Island from the Xbox and Playstation games, the mod also allows you to change cars at random points and adds all of the DLC without EA coming to rip your wallet apart. The DLC is quite fun and you can have lots of random moments with your friends. The mod also allows you to change to any citizen car with any paint scheme which is a nice feature.Only problems that I had. On a Windows 7 Computer it worked fine for a series of time, it would crash ocasionally but that might of been because of my older setup. The game works well with old and new Windows but I had some problems with a Win10 machine, but my friends computer (WIN8) worked fine. I was trying to get the game running with two monitors but then I realised I my older setup was screen center to left which for some reason broke burnout completley but when I disconnected it, the game ran smoothly.You can have hours of fun on any burnout game but especially this one with its free world and ability to choose to do missions when you want to. So I recommend buying this, but remember to play it with friends because it is extremely fun messing around with some areas!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
WARNING!!! I'll be comparing this game to "Burnout Revenge"; it's predecessor.This is the last entry of the main Burnout series, and I feel that it is a strong game, it is really fun to play. But compared to the previous game... it fell short for me. Lemme explain:I used to play Burnout Revenge on my PS2 and I had a blast playing through it, I haven't played it in over 2 years but there are a lot of things missing in Paradise.1. Traffic Checking Sure in this game you can get "Traffick Check Takedown" which is crashing into a traffic car, causing it to lose control and crashing into an oponent... BUT in Revenge if you crashed into the back of a traffic car you could just launch it into oblivion (and possible other racers), in fact, traffic checking was actually a whole game mode in Revenge, where you had to crash into as many cars as possible before you ran out of time, by chaining them and throwing them into Trucks and Busses and oncoming traffic for bonus time and points.In Paradise you can't do it... which I learned the hard way...2. Crash Events Yes you can trigger a crash event by pressing LB+RB on your Xbox controller (not sure on keyboard) but they only serve as a "record" on the different roads of the game... in Revenge they were MASSIVE, you had to launch your car into a heavily transited intersection; you could unlock heavy cars for those events specifically, If you have played "Turbo Dismount" then you'll know how those worked on Revenge, except that once you did enough damage your boost meter would feel and you'd have to mash the boost button to BLOW UP and causing even more damage to other cars and even reach cars that were too far away from you. Beating those events would unlock more ranks, events and cars.3. Burnout TakedownsYou can't do these in Paradise... In Revenge (after you unlock the ability of course), when you crashed in a Road Rage or Race event you could press a button (Don't remember which one) and blow up, taking other racers with you, racking up your score in Road Rage, or diminish your dissadvantage after crashing.4. Double, Triple and more takedownsIn Paradise if you manage to force 2 or more racers into a wall and they all crash, you only get credit for one of those; in Revenge if you do that it would show you the first crash and say "TAKEDOWN!" and immediately shift to the other crashed car and say "Double Takedown" and even if you don't get the camera for the takedowns you still got credit for those... making Road Rage events a lot more satisfying to beat.5. AFTERTOUCHAftertouch is an ability in most Burnout games (At least on Burnout 3, Revenge, and Dominator) where if you crash into a wall or traffic car, you could slow down time and move your car in the air, this means you can place yourself in front of oponents for them to crash into you... AND IT COUNTS AS TAKEDOWNS, which meant that if you made a mistake you could take the competition with you!Unfortunately you can't use aftertouch in Paradise, If you crash you can actually spin if the front wheels are touching the ground... but even if you manage to position yourself in front of someone, it won't count as a takedown... sure it makes them crash and lose their advantage... but it feels a lot more satisfying to read "AFTERTOUCH TAKEDOWN" and even adding a DOUBLE or TRIPLE if you cause 2 or 3 oponents to crash into you. This also means that on Road Rage events you won't get credit for doing that.6. More CarsI like how you unlock cars by smashing them into a wall in Paradise. However in Revenge you were constantly unlocking new cars by getting medals in all of the events, however in Paradise it feels more of a chore to unlock them instead of a rewards...In fact I ALT+F4 out of the game multiple times because I couldn't reach the car I had to unlock and when I finally got close, I do a curve wrong or crash into traffic and completely lose the damn car... Also in Revenge there was a list of objectives in every location (I think there were 9 locations... not sure on that one) and they were pretty much the same, but they were really difficult to beat, The ones I remember the best are: Get a vertical takedown Win a clean race (No crashes) Beat X event in Y ammount of timeThere were more but those are the ones I remember and what do you get for beating all of the objectives?ONE OF THE BEST CARS IN THE GAMEIt was rewarding to beat them.7. Signature TakedownsI think even RIvals for the Nintendo DS had signature takedowns... if you crashed an oponent in a specific spot on an event you'll get multiple angles of the crash and "pictures" AND you'll unlock the signature takedown (actually quite useless but it still feels satisfying to know that you did it.)----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Now that I'm done comparing this one with Revenge I'll express my opinion on the new features the game has.1. Open WorldMeh... to be honest Burnout doesn't need an open world, it has always been about the events and races, but physically reaching each event doesn't really fit with the pace of this game.2. Stunt RunsThey're really fun, I like just jumping all over the place, drifting and finding shortcuts and stunt jumps on the way, And crashing against something finishing your combo feels fait, you crash? start the combo again.3. Time TrialsI don't like how you always have to change cars for these events, you know a little pop-up saying "would you like to change your car?" would be nice for these events, as junk yards are often far away and sometimes I forget which car was I supposed to get into... Although unlocking the improved version of the car feel good for the trouble.4. Gas, Paint and Repair stops The spray stops are ok, and having to repair the car first before experiencing their full potential feels... out of place for Burnout. And I only find Gas stations useful for free roam.What I don't like is that repair stops make the marked man and road rage events FAR TOO EASY...5. Marked Man eventsThey're challenging, I like that. You have to reach the end while you'll being chased by multiple enemies that are constantly shunting and ramming you to wreck you car, it's pretty much Road Rage but it is a race instead of racking up takedowns, BUT you can take those cars down to fill up your boost meter.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------So yeah I'll just put the pros and cons now...Pros Open World Tons of events Lots of cars Stunt jumps, billboards, shortcuts to find and complete. New event typesCons Unlocking cars feels more like a chore than a reward Less features compared to it's predecessor Old event types removed Repair shops make road rage events too easy.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall I recommend this game all the way, I bought it when it was on sale and I encourage you to do it aswell... but to be honest if you come across Burnout Revenge for the PS2/PS3/XBOX360 get that instead.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Bought this game when it was on sale over the cyber monday for pure nostaglia. I 100% completed the game twice on the 360 and was top 100 in the US for ranked racing for over 3 months on the 360. This game is amazing for those of you looking to get it. Be warned though EA doesn't support the Store anymore so if you are looking for the Legendary, Boost Special, or Toy cars from the 360 or PS3 you will have to buy a key online. (Amazon for $10) This ultimate box comes with 2 free bikes and another big content patch. It also comes with the optional Offline Multiplayer Party Pack which was a seperate DLC on the 360 and PS3. Also the Cops and Robbers and Island DLC are NOT released on PC and probably never will be. Multiplayer racing from ranked to freeburn is still support with Voice Chat, no text chat however. Haven't found any controller combatibility apart from a driving wheels. Still a fantastic racing game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												So good!!!  Still my favorite game of all time.  Open world racing, spectacular crashes, awesome soundtrack.  Vehicles: Cars handling is very arcade-y, but very fun.  There are a number of cars with twitchy handling that require more than just throttle mashing to win the races.  A Burning Route time trial event for each car unlocks a slightly upgraded version of that car.  The addition of motorcycles is a nice change of pace with their offline time trial events.Stunt Runs, Road Rages, Marked Man and Race events can be played online or offline.  In addition, there are hundreds of online challenges for 2-8 players.  When you find a good group of online players, it is a lot of fun.Showtime: Crash your way down the road racking up as many points as possible.  Destruction has never been more fun.Road Rules: Set a fast time for every road on the map.  You'll be cursing the traffic but that clean run is so sweet.Criterion, please take a break from Need for Speed and make another Burnout already.Sidenote:  I played this game all the way through to 102% on the PS3 in 2009 and just recently bought it for the PC.  It looks SO much better on the PC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Online population is next to dead and full regulars that exploit or outright cheat. But still, online/offline there is plenty to do in this game. There are three event types (race, stunt run, and road rage [online has challenges outside of these]) and 50+ cars consisting of three types (boost, rage, and stunt) that change how you play to fill up your boost. Your car selection is limited in online events (race, stunt, and rage), but has no restriction in Freeburn (online no event) and while doing online challenges. Offline play usu. requires specific vehicles to complete progress (i.e. dependent on event type). Regardless of online or offline play the entire map is completely open. Online you work with others to complete achievements or participate in events and offline you work to unlock cars.The only issue is that the game will disconnect players from host (no dedicated servers) at times when the hosts start events, most regularly during races. Challenges do not seem to be effected by this issue. And there is no in-game chat ability other than a mic, which, thankfully, you have the ability to mute players if their mic has feedback or they are trolling.

												Not an amazing game in the least, but it is definitely fun.  I really enjoy games that set you up with challenges to beat.  I have never been much of a racing game fan, but this game is not really meant to be taken seriously.  You do crazy stunts, crash your car into others for points, run from other racers chasing you, and just flat out race.  Also, the little mini challenges are nice.  Trying to beat the best time on a certain street really keeps the game interesting.  Just a nice little simple game where you just have to progress, unlock better equipment (cars), and beat your best scores.  I like it and recommend it.

												Great graphics and sound. However the announcer is annoying sometimes. Wish he would stop talking so much.  I also wish the city had people walking around would give the city more life. This edition does not include the dlc island that was only for the xbox however if you search you can find a fan made island made for this game. The game is great fun and I do recommend this game to all. 9/10 a great game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
WARNING!!! I'll be comparing this game to "Burnout Revenge"; it's predecessor.This is the last entry of the main Burnout series, and I feel that it is a strong game, it is really fun to play. But compared to the previous game... it fell short for me. Lemme explain:I used to play Burnout Revenge on my PS2 and I had a blast playing through it, I haven't played it in over 2 years but there are a lot of things missing in Paradise.1. Traffic Checking Sure in this game you can get "Traffick Check Takedown" which is crashing into a traffic car, causing it to lose control and crashing into an oponent... BUT in Revenge if you crashed into the back of a traffic car you could just launch it into oblivion (and possible other racers), in fact, traffic checking was actually a whole game mode in Revenge, where you had to crash into as many cars as possible before you ran out of time, by chaining them and throwing them into Trucks and Busses and oncoming traffic for bonus time and points.In Paradise you can't do it... which I learned the hard way...2. Crash Events Yes you can trigger a crash event by pressing LB+RB on your Xbox controller (not sure on keyboard) but they only serve as a "record" on the different roads of the game... in Revenge they were MASSIVE, you had to launch your car into a heavily transited intersection; you could unlock heavy cars for those events specifically, If you have played "Turbo Dismount" then you'll know how those worked on Revenge, except that once you did enough damage your boost meter would feel and you'd have to mash the boost button to BLOW UP and causing even more damage to other cars and even reach cars that were too far away from you. Beating those events would unlock more ranks, events and cars.3. Burnout TakedownsYou can't do these in Paradise... In Revenge (after you unlock the ability of course), when you crashed in a Road Rage or Race event you could press a button (Don't remember which one) and blow up, taking other racers with you, racking up your score in Road Rage, or diminish your dissadvantage after crashing.4. Double, Triple and more takedownsIn Paradise if you manage to force 2 or more racers into a wall and they all crash, you only get credit for one of those; in Revenge if you do that it would show you the first crash and say "TAKEDOWN!" and immediately shift to the other crashed car and say "Double Takedown" and even if you don't get the camera for the takedowns you still got credit for those... making Road Rage events a lot more satisfying to beat.5. AFTERTOUCHAftertouch is an ability in most Burnout games (At least on Burnout 3, Revenge, and Dominator) where if you crash into a wall or traffic car, you could slow down time and move your car in the air, this means you can place yourself in front of oponents for them to crash into you... AND IT COUNTS AS TAKEDOWNS, which meant that if you made a mistake you could take the competition with you!Unfortunately you can't use aftertouch in Paradise, If you crash you can actually spin if the front wheels are touching the ground... but even if you manage to position yourself in front of someone, it won't count as a takedown... sure it makes them crash and lose their advantage... but it feels a lot more satisfying to read "AFTERTOUCH TAKEDOWN" and even adding a DOUBLE or TRIPLE if you cause 2 or 3 oponents to crash into you. This also means that on Road Rage events you won't get credit for doing that.6. More CarsI like how you unlock cars by smashing them into a wall in Paradise. However in Revenge you were constantly unlocking new cars by getting medals in all of the events, however in Paradise it feels more of a chore to unlock them instead of a rewards...In fact I ALT+F4 out of the game multiple times because I couldn't reach the car I had to unlock and when I finally got close, I do a curve wrong or crash into traffic and completely lose the damn car... Also in Revenge there was a list of objectives in every location (I think there were 9 locations... not sure on that one) and they were pretty much the same, but they were really difficult to beat, The ones I remember the best are: Get a vertical takedown Win a clean race (No crashes) Beat X event in Y ammount of timeThere were more but those are the ones I remember and what do you get for beating all of the objectives?ONE OF THE BEST CARS IN THE GAMEIt was rewarding to beat them.7. Signature TakedownsI think even RIvals for the Nintendo DS had signature takedowns... if you crashed an oponent in a specific spot on an event you'll get multiple angles of the crash and "pictures" AND you'll unlock the signature takedown (actually quite useless but it still feels satisfying to know that you did it.)----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Now that I'm done comparing this one with Revenge I'll express my opinion on the new features the game has.1. Open WorldMeh... to be honest Burnout doesn't need an open world, it has always been about the events and races, but physically reaching each event doesn't really fit with the pace of this game.2. Stunt RunsThey're really fun, I like just jumping all over the place, drifting and finding shortcuts and stunt jumps on the way, And crashing against something finishing your combo feels fait, you crash? start the combo again.3. Time TrialsI don't like how you always have to change cars for these events, you know a little pop-up saying "would you like to change your car?" would be nice for these events, as junk yards are often far away and sometimes I forget which car was I supposed to get into... Although unlocking the improved version of the car feel good for the trouble.4. Gas, Paint and Repair stops The spray stops are ok, and having to repair the car first before experiencing their full potential feels... out of place for Burnout. And I only find Gas stations useful for free roam.What I don't like is that repair stops make the marked man and road rage events FAR TOO EASY...5. Marked Man eventsThey're challenging, I like that. You have to reach the end while you'll being chased by multiple enemies that are constantly shunting and ramming you to wreck you car, it's pretty much Road Rage but it is a race instead of racking up takedowns, BUT you can take those cars down to fill up your boost meter.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------So yeah I'll just put the pros and cons now...Pros Open World Tons of events Lots of cars Stunt jumps, billboards, shortcuts to find and complete. New event typesCons Unlocking cars feels more like a chore than a reward Less features compared to it's predecessor Old event types removed Repair shops make road rage events too easy.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall I recommend this game all the way, I bought it when it was on sale and I encourage you to do it aswell... but to be honest if you come across Burnout Revenge for the PS2/PS3/XBOX360 get that instead.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Great fun, one of the few non-Kart racing games that I truly enjoy playing.  The music selection is wonderful, the car selection is great, and online play is perfection!  Only down side is not as many people online as there used to be, but that is to be expected from a game of this age.  Oh, and the car crashes... those wonderful car crashes... they are the best part.  It's like a city-wide demolition derby and it is as fun as that sounds!One note, if you get a blank white screen when going online, just close it.  It's a leftover from when EA actually supported it with an online store.  Now that the store is gone, all that's left is a blank screen.  It's annoying at first, but you learn to ignore it soon enough.Played using a Logitech E-X5D12 Driving Force Feedback Wireless Wheel Controller.  I had to remap the controls in the game, they were awful, but once it's configured, the experience is amazing!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This is a good racing game.But instead of just racing, you can also take down your enemies, easily the thing that sets the game series Burnout apart from others. And it's very fun. Another unusual thing is that, while you're racing (or are playing the other modes), there are no arrows to guide you, no boundries. You must rely on your mini-map and / or compass to get to the finishing line. The game has a massive open world with over four hundred shortcuts that you can learn in order to get to the finishing line quicker than the others can. There are also some other "collectibles". You also find events (Racing, Marked Man, Road Rage...) only by exploring the map. The main goal of the game is to get a Burnout Driving License, which you can only get by winning the aforementioned events. You get cars every time you upgrade your license, and when you shut down certain cars.The game also has an online mode, where you can play the same events that you can on singleplayer, but with actual people. Sadly, Race is the only properly made event, as the other ones really haven't had much love given to them. When you're not doing an event in multiplayer, you're on freeburn, where you try beating other people's records (no. of barrel rolls, air distance, etc.). It's quite fun, even if it has its flaws.Now, let's talk about the port: it's bad. The online mode doesn't even have a chat. You can only communicate with other people with voice chat. The menus are really odd too. The optimization is alright. I do have some FPS drops in areas with lots of cars and action, but you can kinda blame it on my PC (although I expected it to perform a bit better regardless). The fast menu is also impossible to access unless you have a controller, which is a problem because that's the menu that allows you to change teams in certain multiplayer events such as Road Rage.Overall, it's a good game. And it's cheap. You don't really need a controller, the keyboard works just fine. It has its flaws, but overall you should get it if you're a fan of racing. 8/10

												Burnout: Paradise has something for every type of gamer. If you just like the racing aspect, you got it. Do you just like showcasing cars in action? there's the stunt mode so you can take snapshots of your card in mid-air. Or you're like me and like crashing into♥♥♥♥♥♥and watching it tumble around, that's what road rage mode is for. Also, you can just activate this mode where your car suddenly starts flipping and the objective is to cause as much damage to other cars before you loose momentum.This game still plays as good as when it came out and hasn't felt any older. The world is so big, some people can still get lost in the middle of a heated race in multiplayer. The variety of cars is there and each one drives really differently. I would buy it now since it still has people playing it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												 Burnout Paradise is a game that has taken the open world elements that we have all loved from the past, along with a racing game tied into the formula. Not only does Burnout give players an open world, but uses a great way to unlock cars. There are many ways to unlock cars. From performing the same old race to driving down the highway to smash a rival that is in pursuit, Paradise is very edgy and also easy for players to level up and climb the ranks. Along with the open world and unlockable items, Burnout allows players to experience driving in a whole new level with a Slow-Motion camera designed to see crashes or takedowns in a whole new way. This feature actually makes crashing a little more rewarding (as weird as it sounds) than that of just completing a race. With a great Single-Player along with a fun Multiplayer  Burnout is a must have title in anybody's library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												This game is getting older as we speak. The game is a classic and is really the best Burnout game in the series, I love this game personally and can play it for hours with its multiple missions and many different cars. The cars in this game... Well I love them really, starting the cars driving them at high speeds through the city and the hills. There are many DLCs ,which you know I hate, but there is a definate way to bypass that. The cars are all interesting and really fun to drive, the handling is very easy and you can definatley feel the freedom when you're driving.Firstly the cars in this are awesome! You can get many styles of cars such as: Rage, stunt, street and that wierd turbo thing that only lets you recharge... The entire car system has many different styles of driving, the cars can be stock or the upgraded unlocked version of the original car. You can get mini cars, police cars and many more random types of new cars which can only be found on the origin store. The DLC for paradise island is only avalible for the console versions of this game but you can mod it into the game which adds buggys and a whole new island. The entire games map is massive compared to new games and its nicley detailed, the whole thing has events placed "at every intersection" as explained in the first part of the game which is true! Events on every intersection which can be played again but only to beat your score.The map concludes of beaches, mountains and city scapes with loads of driving to do. I had some technical problems with the game trying to set up multiplayer, EA actually sent me a copy onto my Origin account which then worked. The games multiplayer consists of free drive, races, stunt runs and free races (which is where you set up your own races for your friends). I like playing with my friends because you can have a lot of fun seeing who can get the biggest air alltogether in a certain place or just driving for fun. Multiplayer does have a negative side to it though, its very anoying to setup with multiple game platforms Steam/Origin but I was the only one with this problem.The game does have DLC but noone wants to pay for that so some nice modding community have recreated Paradise Island from the Xbox and Playstation games, the mod also allows you to change cars at random points and adds all of the DLC without EA coming to rip your wallet apart. The DLC is quite fun and you can have lots of random moments with your friends. The mod also allows you to change to any citizen car with any paint scheme which is a nice feature.Only problems that I had. On a Windows 7 Computer it worked fine for a series of time, it would crash ocasionally but that might of been because of my older setup. The game works well with old and new Windows but I had some problems with a Win10 machine, but my friends computer (WIN8) worked fine. I was trying to get the game running with two monitors but then I realised I my older setup was screen center to left which for some reason broke burnout completley but when I disconnected it, the game ran smoothly.You can have hours of fun on any burnout game but especially this one with its free world and ability to choose to do missions when you want to. So I recommend buying this, but remember to play it with friends because it is extremely fun messing around with some areas!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												It's some great old-school racing fun, with a ton of content for a very small price.You have an upgrade path with lots of cars in three main groups: speed, stunt and destruction. You collect these as you win races and challenges, both as rewards and as target which you have to take down in order to collect them.You can play offline with challenges from simple races, not-so-simple races, stunt challenges and races where you are the target for other cars who are trying to destroy your vehicle.You can also play online with friends and strangers, setting up races, simple ones or with multiple check points, car limits, boost limits or a free-for all. You will need a free EA/Origin account to play online and to add friends to your friends list requires installing Origin.There are some annoying quirks (the UI navigation involves ESC, F1, F2 and Backspace!) and the theme song that plays every time you launch the game (To stop it: Go to Steam\steamapps\common\Burnout(TM) Paradise The Ultimate Box\SOUND\STREAMS and replace the file GUNS_AND_ROSES.SNS with a blank text file of the same name (including extension)) and there's this blank page that pops up requiring you to hit "Return to Game" every so often in the menu (The fix to that is to add  127.0.0.1 portal.burnoutweb.ea.com to your hosts file). I guess that's some hangover they forgot to fix when they stopped supporting whatever was on that page, but once you've done that, it's plain sailing.It's a good little game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2011
												Wow, I had such a great time with this game on the PS3. I played it for over 100 hours and it's still a great game ! The graphics were (are) amazing, and it reminded me a bit of Midtown Madness, another favorite of mine. There are no pedestrians in this game - I'd normally complain about this -  but there is just so much traffic and you're driving at such high speeds that you'll hardly ever notice there's not a person to be found in this game. There are a lot of cars. You can win them by finishing races or by crashing into them while driving around (which reminded me of Chase HQ, another excellent chasing game). The crashes look spec-ta-cu-lar and there's just so much to do ! Destroy billboards, crash into gates, win cars, win races, do stunts; you name it, it's there. One of the best (yes, the BEST !) racing games ever. Hoping for a sequel. Fingers crossed.[Rating: 90/100]

												This is a game ive had for a while now, but I've only recently started playing a lot of. Its one of the most origininal driving games I think I've ever seen. It completly throws the generic 'standard circuit' racing convention and replaced it with an open city where you have to get from point A to B by choosing which roads to take while still driving your opponents into the ground (quite literally). The graphics side to this game are... ok but  if you stop your car for a moment and actually look around. the scenery seems less authentic and 2D (but you will get this in EVERY racing game becuase why the hell have you stopped your car to look at the scenery). The multiplayer in this is probably what makes it most interesting and fun. Mulitple different modes, not just racing but co-op challenges, sandbox mode A.K.A freeburn and all the other crazy stuff in between.8/10Deffinaltley one to buy especially if you have some friends to play online with you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9
												I orignally had this game on the PS3, but I have since sold the console and have purchased it for PC.Burnout Paradise is one of the few racing games that I have seen that offers so much freedom. The game takes place in a giant open world map populated with objective challenges like races, stunt competitions, and road rage (take out other cars) competitions. Additionally, the world incentivises you to explore by making you search for hidden areas, big jumps, and billboards to smash through. There are many billboards that seem impossible to access, but after looking around, you'll finally find the hidden jump needed to access it.The game features very satisfying driving mechanics that allow you to drift around corners with ease. At the same time, the game has over 100 different cars that all have a very unique handling behavior and charm. You will gradually unlock faster and more resilient cars as you complete challenges across the map. Even after unlocking the late game cars, I still like to drive around in the earlier cars from time to time for their appearance and driving experience.The online mode of the game is also really entertaining. You can freely roam around and the city and chase after your friends to try and take them down. Alternatively, you can team up with your friends to try and complete online challenges. Some challenges are quite difficult, as they require a specific number of players and require you to complete a task under a time limit. However, the reward for completing all of the online tasks is a very exclusive (and dapper) car.Overall, one of my favorite car/racing games I have ever played because of the freedom, exploration, and online activities. The downside to the game is it is no longer updated, so there are many patches needed for minor bugfixes and stability fixes on newer operating systems.As many have said, "The Ultimate Box" does not include the DLC of Big Surf Island, the legendary cars, or the toy cars. Despite the exclusion of DLC, this game is definately worth the buy during a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2011
												Wow, I had such a great time with this game on the PS3. I played it for over 100 hours and it's still a great game ! The graphics were (are) amazing, and it reminded me a bit of Midtown Madness, another favorite of mine. There are no pedestrians in this game - I'd normally complain about this -  but there is just so much traffic and you're driving at such high speeds that you'll hardly ever notice there's not a person to be found in this game. There are a lot of cars. You can win them by finishing races or by crashing into them while driving around (which reminded me of Chase HQ, another excellent chasing game). The crashes look spec-ta-cu-lar and there's just so much to do ! Destroy billboards, crash into gates, win cars, win races, do stunts; you name it, it's there. One of the best (yes, the BEST !) racing games ever. Hoping for a sequel. Fingers crossed.[Rating: 90/100]

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												The best arcade racing game available for PC. Simple as that. I would rank this at number 3 in the Burnout franchise with Burnout: Revenge coming as number one and Burnout 3 coming second. The gameplay in this game gets really repetitive after you reach 50% of total progress but the rush never ends. Graphics and sound (AND the soundtrack) are very, very nice considering this is now 5 years old and it works without a hiccup on any modern PC (first time played it on a dual core Athlon X2 3000+ with 2GB RAM and a HD 4670 and it never ever slowed down), all settings maxed out. I would recommend this to anyone even remotely interested in racing games, it's worth every penny. I would give it 8.8/10.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												The game is immense and easily my favorite car game of all time.75 cars in the basic pack, each with a basic "Type" which is how it accumulates boost. You'll be doing a lot of boosting. And they all feel a little different than one another. They have since added several different packs of cars, so many that I honestly can't count, with their own challenges. Every stoplight in the game is a different mission. The game itself is pretty straightforward, there's a location at each compass point of the city at which all the challenges end, and they come in a few different flavors loosely coinciding with the car types. Beyond that, drive around a big♥♥♥♥♥city at enormous speed, creating breathtaking car crashes and listening to classic rock and trying to get your next car unlock. Cons: Not gameplay related, but rather EA's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port programming. You will probably need to configure your own controls, although the game makes it pretty painless. I also had a problem caused by the game's attempt to take my picture for my driver's license (don't bother, it's VERY glitchy, but a cool idea)--every time I tried to open the menu it would crash. Fixed it by turning off the webcam driver (I don't have a webcam) in my control panel and it's been running smoothly ever since.Anyway, technical problems aside, this is the Skyrim of car games and you should get it if you have even a passing interest. I don't like racing games but I love this damn game. For 5$ in a sale, it's a no-brainer.Edit: in case you were concerned that my playtime is too low to be this positive, I have at least 30-40 hours on the XBox version. I was very happy to return it to my library on steam by buying it a second time.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Burnout Paradise is a great game. Probably one of the best open world games that I've played. I might be a bit bias since this game brings so much nostalgia when I used to just play this with friends all night on Xbox360 and singing the Guns n Roses song "Paradise City". Info: Burnout Paradise was made in 2009 so don't expect 4K graphics but it does still have good quality graphics. In PC requirements circumstances you can play this  game on max vid settings on mostly any PC or to be more specific you can run it on high if you get 40 Frames on CSGO,GMod,LoL. Here is a short P&C list and overall review for you guysPro's-Simple and very easy to jump into game-Open World that actually doesn't get boring -Soundtrack mix is gnarly-Jumps are f'ing awesome-Cinematic Cams are cool-Concept of different cars and EventsCon's-EA account login is stupid-Multiplayer is dead(who cares  though)-No more add ons you can buy since it's outdated-Bit glitchy at timesOverall Review: A must buy for all avid Racing or Open World gamers. No question that this is probably one of the best games that EA has made.

If you like over the top racing action, you can't do much better than Burnout Paradise!

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Back in my PS2 days I owned Burnout 2 and Takedown and loved the games - played them to bits. When I saw this was up for grabs on a  Steam sale I jumped at the chance.The game is not quite what I was expecting. It's very different to what I thought it would be. That's not to say some of the changes are not for the better, but on the other hand, some aren't.Graphics look brilliant, and the cars still have that same Burnout "feel" to them. The game modes all make a return too - but this time in an open world map. Think NFSU 2 and you will be on the right tracks. This is great, but you seem to spent a lot of time driving around for no reason. I would much prefer to just race and perform the stages without this unnecessary addition. The races themselves also suffer from the same problem of being given too much freedom - you will accidentally go the wrong way because you are concentrating on driving and not constantly looking at the map.O yes, and no 2 player split screen? Not good :-(Bar the problems I have with it though, it's still a good game. Burnout fans will find something to their liking here.Jimbo Rating: 5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												I have been playing this game since it was released in 2008, and still absolutely love it. To me it is the definitive arcade style racing game that nothing else since has come close to.AFAIK it was the first Xbox 360 racing game to run at 60fps and immediately that made all the difference not just in visuals but in amazingly tight controls that are responsive even in the fastest cars the game has to offer, and they are very fast! Even though they run it at 60fps, the visuals are only now starting to get surpassed by rival games, but the gameplay is still king.It was a divisive game when it came out due to its open world sandbox style that immediately alienated the majority of people who tried the demo and I think it never got the recognition it deserved because of that. The sandbox world is actually the games strength, rather than be another arcade style race from a-b on a set route, in BP you needed to learn your way around the game world, the more you learned, the better you get. The game world is a staggering achievement, and even now after playing it for years, I am still finding new things.As the game is very cheap now, I would recommend it to anyone who likes arcade style racing games, put the effort in to playing and learning it, and it will reward you with one of the best games ever.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												One of the best racing games out there. No matter how many years have passed since it launched, I still come back to it to have fun racing and crashing cars.HOWEVER, beware many people, including myself, are having problems starting up the game. I believe the game servers shutdown, and ever since it's been a pain to get it working. Startup game homepage (there is an ingame browser that starts everytime you start the game, before opening the actual game) is broken, so working around this to get the game working is a painful process, unless criterion releases a game patch.In the mean time, go to the file burnoutparadise.exe location (right click in steam game, properties, browse file location), and then in windows explorer right click the burnoutparadise.exe file, set it in compatibility with windows xp sp3, and that will do it. It did it for me, after a research on the web on how to make it work.If you have the option to get this game on console, is a different story. The consoles work with no problem (ps3 and xbox 360), but the game will not be as beautiful as it is on PC. It's your choice.One of my favorite racing games of all time.

												I'll be completely honest here, I installed this with pretty low hopes. I've seen what Criterion have done to the NFS franchise, which wasn't exactly stellar but it was fun, and figured they'd done more of the same with the Burnout series. But I am really enjoying this so far. The driving is direct and responsive, taking down an aggro car with a speed car is super satisfying too, that slow mo crash gives you that much loved moment of smugness. Graphically it's quite pretty for its year and it runs really well even on low end machines. So in summation, it's a damn fun game, the shelf life to cost ratio is damn high too. I'd recommend this game to anyone that enjoys racing games and those that enjoy a good hit and run, arcade style racer too.

												Burnout Paradise was a surprise for me. And a good one at that. bought it for around a dollar, didn't expect alot from the game, but what i found was one of the most enjoyable racing experiences i have ever had, up there with need for speed most wanted 2005. The physics in the game are really well made, and the chrashes are as cinematic as it gets, for one of the first times i actually enjoyed crashing my cars, so i could see it getting smashed in slow motion. Crashing was never so fun. The biggest problem in the game for me is that there's one waypoint system of any sort, even while you're racing, sometimes you will get lost or take a wrong turn just to find out that the road you're taking won't lead to the finsih line, but once you get used to the city, you will know it as you know the palm of your hand. Burnout paradise is deffinerely worth picking up because the amount of fun to be had here is insane. I also want to point out how good the soundtrack is, and if you're a rock fan, these words will be enough for you : They axctually have a guns n' roses track in this game. I think thats nuff said.TL;DR JUST BUY IT NOW

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
GraphicsWell detailed game. You can read (albeit dangerous) the license plates on other cars. The lighting from the sun shines off high gloss paint jobs like in real life. The small detail damages are realistic; if you broke a headlamp it stays broken and doesn’t light up. The back ground is realistic enough to tell distance. I’ve played this at both regular television and hi definition 1080p while it is still good at the lowest setting I highly recommend the playing at the highest possible detail.Sound and MusicYou can tell from just driving around what types of cars are around you with even having to look at that area. The screeching of the tires to the roar of an engine is clear with any vehicle you use. Now the music, quantity or quality wise you will not be disappointed. There are a lot of songs that play while driving around so chances are if you play for an hour or two, you will not hear the same song twice. And you don’t like a particular song you can always take if off the play list. One should note that a good portion of songs are the same songs from older Burnout Games.Game PlayAs you win events you upgrade your license. The higher the license, the larger amount of vehicles you will be able to use. These events are littered all thought Paradise City. To start the event simple pull up to a light to start it.Here is the events.Races: Standard Race. From one to seven other opponents you drive to a specific end point.Road Rage: Timed Event. You use your vehicle as a battering ram to smash other vehicles into traffic, walls or other hard objects. Target amount is usually displayed. Event ends when either you take to much damage or time ends.Marked Man: Almost like a race. You goal is to reach one destination while four other computer cars try to inflict enough damage to keep you from reaching your destination.Stunts: Use your vehicle like a little acrobat, jumping off ramps, crashing bill boards and doing spins. The more you do in a sequence the more points you get. There is a target score to get per event.Burning Route: One route per vehicle. It’s a timed race where you just have to get to the finish line by a certain time using a certain vehicle. Every route you finish unlocks a upgraded version of the vehicle used.All these events get a bit more difficult as the game wears on but not that much more. I would say once you get used to the way the game plays you find that most of these events range from easy (one or two attempts) to medium (fifteen minutes maximum).Now there are a few side events or tasks that are fun to do. Running certain billboards, barriers, and super jumps. They are littered everywhere, cant be avoided just driving around. There are few hidden but find to fun all of them and as a reward for finding all it unlocks more vehicles. There are also two events per street, one is time trails and the other is showtime. Showtime is just you bouncing around hitting vehicles for points.Online play is quite fun with tasks and races, connections are usually stable. One thing I like is with Xbox Live Vision take a photo of you when you get taken out by another drive and sent to the aggressor. The online experience is a whole new game in itself and worth playing.NegativesAlthough it’s a very good game here is a few of the things I didn’t like. Showtime is very repetitive in the sense you have to do it to all 64 streets of Paradise City. Also Showtime replaced Crash from previous games. The on line challenges are very repetitive where if 2 players you have to do it for 7 players. And some of them are very very basic like driving in oncoming traffic. Also while doing online challenges if one person get disconnected, the challenges are cancelled. The difficulty level is somewhat misleading as the more cars you unlock the easier the game is when trying to do the events.One last thing that kind of surprised me is the amount of advertising in the game, from billboards to vans there is way too much advertising in this game. To show how much advertising there are four unlockable cars, all of them are plastered with the names.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2013
												I'm not really a fan of racing games... but Burnout is something that I really like and enjoy. Around the fictional setting of Paradise City cars are meant to be smashed, shortcuts and super jumps discovered, and multiple routes toward the same finish line exploited. Winning challenges nets you new rides and better licenses to take on more difficult challenges. The city itself isn't a metropolis teeming with life--you won't see pedestrians wandering around or anything like that--but there's plenty of traffic on the roads and shortcuts to discover as you freely drive around. While in the confines of your car you can pull up at stoplights to trigger events of different types, like stunt challenges, races, marked man (reach a finish line while other drivers try to smash you to bits) and road rage (destroy a set number of cars within a time limit) events, as well as timed runs. The soundtrack is really nice because it suits the atmosphere of the game. What could possibly be better than speeding down the highway through the thick traffic while being chased by 3 heavily armored vehicles and listening to some classic music. The game has a pretty big and nice collection of classic tracks that I enjoy most. Anyway, if you're not really into racing games, but you do want to play something like that - Burnout it is.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												As someone who loves racing games, this one just never clicked for me. I sunk a good 50 hours into it back in the day on console and it was just okay back then. Any way you slice it, it is easily the worst of all the Burnout games (it's a shame the better games never made their way onto Steam). While a bit disappointing, Paradise was still a solid game at it's time, but it simply hasn't aged well. The city is bland, the cars handle very poorly and the takedown system gets really annoying over time. It seems we've had a deluge of open world racing games since this one launched, and with the exception of NFS Rivals, I'd say all of them are superior to Paradise in one way or another. Even The Crew, despite suffering dreadful gameplay, has a much more vivid and engaging world than Paradise. Not that this is a bad game, it's just the weakest in the series, below par when compared to more recent open-world racers, and for me, the “ultimate” kicker that turns this from a “buy during a steam sale” into a “no way”, is the fact that the game is blatantly falsely advertised. What EA meant by ultimate is a mystery seeing as it does not contain the DLC. Big Surf island, the most important piece of DLC released was never even ported to PC, and the rest of the DLC you have to purchase through Origin. How exactly is that “The Ultimate” edition?

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
Classic Burnout Destruction in a HUGE Open World Map


YouTube™ Video: Burnout Paradise: The Ultimate Box || Open World Destruction Racing [PC] 

			Views: 153		

			Classic Burnout Destruction in a HUGE Open World Map + Ridiculously fast crazy gameplay + Lots of cars to unlock and use + Very large open-world map to explore and race on + No GPS navigation, so you...		

+ Ridiculously fast crazy gameplay+ Lots of cars to unlock and use+ Very large open-world map to explore and race on+ No GPS navigation, so you are forced to plot your own course in races+ Plenty of events+ Takedown mode is extremely fun+ Great Soundtrack with a variety of pop / rock (~100 songs total)+ Great damage physics- Missing something that made previous Burnouts great like Crash Mode- Most all the races take place in a urban / city environment, wish there was more rural races and perhaps some different weather- Can get a bit repetitive quickly- Some events drag on a bit too long even after you completed the goal- lacks a story- no upgrade system, currency, and the progession is kind of slow (you basically just win events to upgrade your license to unlock better cars to race in faster events)[Side Note: most of my time played was through Origin, so it won't show I have much time on Steam]

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												I don't know what to say about this, it was half good and half bad but I can't pick the "IDK" rating to this. I liked the soundtrack, quality and cars on this game. My dislikes are bikes, crappy controls at the start (I wouldn't have problems if I changed them to Valve-like later. Oh and, after a few tries it's not a bad thing), takes too long to get into my destination and I don't even know where to go and I screw up (but then I realized there's "Easydrive"), I can't hear a such THING when I have every sound level the highest of my game (I don't want to have more than 10% volume, because then I would be ear♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by a Microphone beep/voices or Steam message/online sounds. But then it's normal...) and no crashbreaker on Showtime or it's not like a Crash mode anyways. The showtime is like the recent game "Burnout CRASH!" with infinite Aftertouch function instead of Crashbreaker and it ends only when you run out of boost and your car stops. Also why are the records so impressive (minimum a million dollars) on this mode?Another problem is that unfortunately Electronic Arts has abandoned the in-game Burnout Store, which makes it impossible to buy the rest of this game's DLC (Cops and Robbers, Toys, etc.) unless someone knows how to use Amazon. They are still purchasable on Xbox 360 however.There's also a DJ guy that talks random♥♥♥♥♥♥between music tracks and tells the objective of many races/events, just like in Burnout 3, except this is totally not our beloved Stryker but that ♥♥♥♥er named "DJ Atomika" from the SSX series. Didn't you know that Stryker already has a job as a DJ for KROQ-FM and he was sent to EA Studios as a guest for just one time? It's not like he's gonna be a Crash FM DJ for every single game for the Burnout series, but still, he was the best in my opinion.Don't know about you, but it personally looks like Rockstar Games' Midnight Club with a few of Need for Speed's functions slapped on. Overall 6.4/10. Although earlier I was like a "♥♥♥♥♥ZOMFG DIS GAEM IZ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-1/10 MAEK BORNOWT TREE ON STIM!!11" guy, but then it was my first time playing...

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Still the best racing game ever!Critereon Games single-handedly deliver the fastest, most intense racing thrills in gaming, and Burnout Paradise remains their greatest installment. The sense of speed is riveting, and each vehicle has a distinct, believable handling that allows for strategic use for the vast array of events. The visuals are still nice, though the car models look FAR better than the admittedly dull and flat environments. It's not a demanding title, either, as I am playing on an Asus laptop with a dual-core i7 Skylake, 12GB ram, and a measly Nvidia 940M with 2GB DDR3 VRAM, and the only settting I need to dial back is ambient occlusion. If there is one complaint I have it's that the soundtrack is awful. Truly awful. But the crashes are sick, so I'm a happy camper. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												"Take me down To the Paradise City where the sign is green and the cars are pretty. I want you please, take me home!"(The play hours are low because this is my second purchase of the game after my first physical copy was broken [and the last installed game were removed long time ago] and I felt I wanted to be a bit nostalgic after I saw the Steam discount).So, Burnout Paradise is essentially a Burnout game, but with open world areas that become an ultimate playground of destruction. I essentially love this games and I wanna describe it in some form of pros and cons:Pros:- OPEN WORLD, BABY! This is what many Burnout fans wanted for a long time!- Vehicles variety. Besides a bunch of muscle cars, sports cars, super cars, and track cars, there are many everyday cars to choose from. You want to drive a sedan? You got it! Want to fool around in a van? There, have some awesome van! Want to haul your family in a station wagon? We got that for you!- Rewarding activities. Besides racing, road rage, stunt run, burning routes, and marked man, you can have plenty of side activities that sure are rewarding! form smashing billboards and gates, stunt jump, beating record time on certain streets, and also, my favourite, showtime! Which will be explained on the next point.- SHOWTIME! It's basically a good ol' crash event since Burnout 3, but there are no Crashbreaker. You use your boost to lift your car and move it around. Hitting traffic will refill your boost, and the best part is? YOU CAN ACTUALLY HAVE UNLIMITED SPACE TO DO YOUR SHOWTIME! You can basically start a Showtime at E. Crawford Dr. and end up with your boost tank empty at the South Bay Expressway, which is from north point of Paradise to the south point of it!- Diverse driving physics. Every cars in the game handles differently, which is a plus point for added realism. For example, when you drive the Carson 500GT, The car handles very slippery and each time you gas it, the rear tire will turn vigorously. But, when you drive cars like Carson Grand Marais, it handles like a boat. Hard to steer, and require e-brake to turn it sharply.- Day and night cycle. YES! There's finally a day and night cycle for thhis game, and it's a plus point for it!Cons:- Racing. What is lacking from the racing segment of the game is that you can only have point-to-point race in this game, There is no circuit mode which I kinda missed from the previous Burnout game.- Paintjob. Ugh. I pretty much dislike paintjobs on certain cars in the game. Wish there is an option to choose "no-paintjob" in certain vehicles.- Traffic variety. Many of us know that there were semi truck, industrial trucks, and RVs in the game. But unfortunately, these were cut content, and it's a shame that they were cut them. It adds plenty of realism if those were added (and also adds plenty vehicles to wreck in Showtime mode).Overall, it's a great game, alhough there are some lackings, but those are covered with the pros that given.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I got so many mixed feelings about this game.I love racing games but I kinda hate it if they turn out to be a chore to finish them..I'll be short and simple on this.pros:-Very nice set of cars.-Great physics and animations.-Some times the car damage after crashes is impressive and the crash effects are very cool -Couple of nice mechanisms including auto repair and auto nitro-fill stations during races-Free roam map-Graphics are totally ok for its time of release.-Nice music selections.cons:-The way the races are set on the map; totally like a NFS Underground 2 ripoff -Annoyingly repetitive; once you level up during the game you got to re-run 90% of the races on the map with just a +10% of extra new race points all over.-Hard to get through if you are not too good with racing games; constant random traffic that makes you wreck your car way to easy even if you are 5 meters away from finish.-Respawn, cut scene, crash cinematics cannot be skipped, you lose like more than 5% of your gameplay time for no reason.-They totally ruin the fun of the game with the whole aggresive racing idea; i got more stressed than mentally rewarded after playing this.average:it's worth playing, the price is low anyway and you can get it cheaper during special offers. don't keep your expectations too high and enjoy the ride. don't buy this unless you are a hardcore racing games fanatic.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2013
												One of the better racing games I've played on steam, despite some serious flaws.What it is:- All races played in the overworld- Traffic is present- No car upgrades, customization, or tuning- Car handling is arcade, not simulation- Several game modes, but only two (race and stunt) are worth playing- Most time is spent driving, not in menus- Exploration and finding secret sortcuts plays a big partCons:- Unskippable crash cam gets very annoying very quickly- No way to instantly restart a race. If you want to retry a race YOU MUST DRIVE BACK TO THE STARTING LINE.- Repairing your car or switching cars between races requires driving to a repair shop or junkyard, which is extremely tedious.- The menus are incredibly unintuitive (I had to google search to figure out how to quit the game and how to quit an event)Pros:- Exploration and finding secrets is really rewarding- The stunts are just awesome- Car handling is good- It is fun, despite the cons.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The gameplay is incredibly arcady. It's nothing like other racing games. It's really fun cruising around with your buddy around Paradise city but other than that the game didn't really hold on to me. I guess some people may enjoy it but I think that it isn't actually an amazing game. It's more of a game you play when you don't have nothing better to do and you've got time to waste. If you like arcady driving controls then this is a must get, if you are a fan of need for speed or forza or grand turismo first try this game before buying it. It's not really for everyone. And if you decide to play it don't judge it rashly, because the driving is really diffrent then in other games, you gotta let it sink in. Oh and graphicly this game being that it's from 2009 is bloody amazing.TL;DR: If you don't like arcade racing games don't get it but try it, if you like arcade racing games get it. NOW!

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Honestly, I just find this game boring. It's not challenging. "Here's a race, just drive down this straight road. Oh, great, you've done it! Here's a new car!" Seriously? Even with a B-licence greatest challenge is not to miss a road during a race, which happens way too easy, because the mini-map doesn't rotate in your driving-direction. But even when you take the wrong exit you can still win the race, because your opponents are pretty slow. So just drive on, if you get totally lost, there's a way to restart the race anyway. Even though you can't win anymore (2nd place doesn't count), you have to finish. Then drive back and start again. The open-world-A-to-B-races just make you take the easiest (straight) road again and again. Because they work. Looking for a cool shortcut? Trying another route? Way to risky. Trying to break through a wooden fence may be succesfull... or end in a boring, unskippable slow-mo-crash-sequence. And not every crossing on the map is really one, because the road-height-levels aren't displayed.There are good things about this game. The world is nice, many things to "collect", great soundtrack. But for me there was nothing motivating.  I tried several times to find something. Something challenging. Mostly I left the game after about 30 minutes, because I couldn't find it. I guess I'll go back to NFS Most Wanted (2005) again...
